story:
Who We Are

We are 5 students from a high school in North Charleston, South Carolina attempting to go on the trip of a lifetime to Costa Rica in June 2013. We are members of the National Honor Society of our school, which means we excel in leadership, character, scholarship, and service. Working hard throughout our years at school, has given us some hope that our hard work could be rewarded with an educational trip to Costa Rica. We have many aspirations in becoming a multitude of professions such as: an engineer, veterinarian, doctor, politician, and teacher, and we feel this trip could greatly benefit our goals. Most of us have barely been out of the state, let alone the country, and this presents us with an exciting opportunity. All the new experiences and cultural exposure while traveling through Costa Rica, will serve as life-long lessons for us as we grow and will undoubtedly change our perspective of ourselves and even our place in the world. While we have set our goals high, we can't do this without you. Many of us come from low income families and our collective goal of $10,000 seems unattainable. We have been struggling and working hard all year, but we still have a long way to go. We understand we have a lot of obstacles in our way, but we won't let our zip code, our family's income, nor any of the other hardships prevent us from reaching our goals. We forever thank you for reading about our story and donating to our cause. By donating you are improving our lives and our education. 

 

Why This Is Important To Us

Educational travel is a key component of our new globally-focused curriculum. The opportunity to witness new cultures firsthand and experience history typically only learned in a textbook is one that only enhances a student’s enthusiasm for learning. By traveling to Costa Rica, we have an excellent opportunity to earn an elective credit toward our education. This credit will help us when we apply for college because colleges look for applicants who have international experience. More colleges and universities are making cultural awareness part of the curriculum, and no matter what their college prospects are, experiencing life abroad will give us an edge on college applications.

"To see the exotic places, meet new people, and actually go somewhere new is thrilling to think about. Traveling through forests, zip lining through trees, riding horses, and seeing real volcanoes would be an experience I would NEVER forget!"

"Going to Costa Rica would be an amazing experience for me. It's an educational trip, while having fun! Traveling around the world is my dream. This Costa Rica trip would make a dream come true. It would be a start to a wonderful adventure. I can't wait to go!"

"I'm excited to see everything! Learn about a new culture, view exotic landscapes, eat new food, hear a local language, get out of my comfort zone, zip line, kayak, fly in an airplane, visit a local school, learn about the rainforest, and observe its nature and all the animals. I want to be a vet, so seeing monkeys everywhere is going to be fascinating!"

 

The Trip

We will be in Costa Rica for 9 days. During our trip to Costa Rica we will be able to visit important landmarks such as the Pas Volcano and hotsprings, zipline through the canopy in the Santa Elena Cloud Forest, visit a local school, and hike Manuel Antonio National Park to learn about a broad range of flora and fauna and how to protect the rainforest.


Your generous donation will help one student make his or her dream come true. Your money will go towards:

Round-trip flights, transportation within Costa Rica, 8 overnight stays in hotels, 3 meals daily, full-time tour director, comprehensive sightseeing of natural attractions, and entrance to INBioparque • Poás Volcano • Hot springs • Lake Arenal kayaking • La Fortuna Waterfall • Santa Elena Cloud Forest • Canopy adventure • Carara Biological Reserve • Manuel Antonio National Park •  Whitewater rafting • horseback riding •  folklore evening with locals
 
If you wish to see our itinerary, you can visit http://www.eftours.com/educational-tours/tour-detail.aspx?code=COS&year=2013
 
 

More Ways To Help

Obviously, a financial contribution to our group would be more than fantastic, but if that isn't in your budget, that's ok! We'd love to have you share our indiegogo link with your family, friends, coworkers, students, or anyone that would be willing to help. Don't forget to use indiegogo's share tools, and of course, make some noise about our campaign through Twitter or Facebook!

 

We really appreciate your assistance and thank you in advance for your support.

story:
The Project

As a senior at The Ross School, I have a unique opportunity: I'll be spending my last year of high school focusing on a personal passion. Our “Senior Project” is something Ross students think about - and plan for - as soon as we start high school.

Cars have been a passion of mine for as long as I can remember. In fact, if you ask my parents, they’ll say I’ve been pointing at cars and trucks since before I could talk. As a kid, my room was filled with Matchbox and Hot Wheels, my shirts, sheets and walls were covered in cars and trucks, and I would only read books and watch videos with automotive themes. My first car was a battery operated Fisher Price Jeep that I drove endlessly around the backyard, navigating in and out of the orange cones that my folks had cheerfully put out for me.

As I got older, my tastes matured, but my passion remained. I started watching the British TV show “Top Gear,” going to the Auto Show at the Javits center every year, playing driving simulator games on my Playstation, and challenging myself to identify any car on the road, type and model, at a single glance.

During my freshman year of high school, I spent three weeks interning at Joe’s Garage in Southampton, under the mentorship of Joe Frizell. That took my passion one step further, by allowing me to learn about the inside of a car as well as the outside. It was also the first time it occurred to me that I might, one day, restore a classic car of my own… maybe even for my Senior Project.

I started saving up - birthday and Christmas gifts, and later, paychecks - and over the course of the past four years, I finally accumulated the funds to purchase a fixer-upper. 

This past June, after several months of dreaming and searching, I found the project car of my dreams: a 1966 Mustang Coupe. 

I'll be doing as much of the work myself as I can, and documenting every step on my blog, www.mustangsam.net, as well as via a short Before-and-After film that will be part of my final presentation. In addition to the engineering, mechanics and design lessons I will be learning, I am experiminenting with entrepreneurship by building and following a budget, launching this IndieGogo fundraising campiagn, and continuing to develop strength in my other two passions: computers and film-making. 

But I need help funding the restoration. Thank you for any and all support you can provide in realizing this long-held dream... (and strengthening my college transcript in the process!)

How You Can Help

The entire project encompasses three parts:

1 - Mechical, Interior and Exterior Work on the Car Itself

2 - Creating and Maintaining the Budget and Fundraising Campaign  

3 - Documenting the Entire Process via the MustangSam.net Blog, photos, video and the Before-and-After Film.

I have built a budget based on estimates from Joe's Garage, Aventura Motors, CJ Pony Parts and other local automotive experts/consultants. I am looking to raise $10,000 to cover most of the costs of the project, as follows:

Mechanical work

  • New brakes
  • Shocks
  • Repair power steering leak
  • Wheel cylinders, bearings and differentials
  • Wheel alignment

Interior Replacements/Repairs 

  • New/repair front seats
  • Center console
  • Instrument panel
  • Glove compartment
  • Seatbelts
  • FM/AM radio
  • Carpeting - interior and trunk
  • Interior/Running iights
  • Steering wheel

Exterior Repairs

  • Windshield Repair/Replace
  • Replace broken trim
  • Rust under right rear floorpan
  • PAINT JOB
  • Reverse light
  • Wiper Blades

Other

  • Sony NEX-5RK/B for documenting
  • Car Cover
  • Canopy
  • Misc. tools/supplies for making repairs

You can view the budget-in-progress on the Gallery page here, or on my blog at www.mustangsam.net

Acknowledging Your Support

Everyone who contributes will be acknowledged on (and have access to) my blog, as well as the Before-and-After film.

Those that are able to make major contributions will also receive a custom-made baseball cap with the "Pony" logo and "Mustang Sam Champion" on it, and will be invited for an exclusive spin in the Pony, with the music and beverage of their choice!

Needless to say, I am immensely grateful for whatever support you can provide, at any level.

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that some people can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help.  You can spread the word by letting friends and family members know about the project. (Indiegogo has a bunch of "share" tools you can use to make it easier.)

Thank you for your support!

story:
Thank you! 

We were able to purchase a digital keyboard with the $795 contribution for Round 1! 

Please go to the campaign link below to donate for Round 2.

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/help-fund-the-future-of-austin-music-round-2


This is Round 1 of a two part campaign and is now closed. 




Community

Austin, Texas based community organization Envision. Design. Create. in partnership with Austin Blues Society would like to thank you for your interest in promoting equality in music education.

Austin, Texas is known as the “Live Music Capital of the World” so we decided to ask the community to come together in support of elevating the music program at a local school to meet the high music standards of the City of Austin. 

The school in question is Mary Jane Sims Elementary School located in East Austin. Sims Elementary School is located on 12th and Springdale. This school is a Title I school and 97% of the children are on the free lunch program.

As such, many of the scholars do not have access to music instruments at home and the school music program is their first and sometimes only introduction to music theory and creation.

Back Story

The founder of Envision. Design. Create., Amberly Russell, volunteered with an after school program at Sims Elem. in 2012 and decided to lead a social good campaign to elevate the school through four main avenues -nature, technology, art and music. Find more info at www.envisiondesigncreate.org

Where Your Funds Are Going

Currently, the students are performing school recitals on old risers with no safety backing. Our first goal is to purchase new risers with safety rails that are easily portable.

Secondly, the music teacher is using his own voice to teach the children scales, melody and harmony. That is not a sufficient method for his workload. Technology in the room is lacking and also does not make up for this deficiency. We would like to buy a keyboard for the classroom.

Funds will also be used to purchase percussion instruments for younger children, hand drums, mallets, xylophones, etc. The current state of percussion instruments are shabby. A local music company called Strait Music has graciously offered to give us deep discounts on all equipment purchased through them!

Any remaining funds will be used to purchase secure lockers for instruments and to upgrade the technology in the room, i.e. projector, screen and speakers.

While in-kind donations are very considerate, we want these children to have new equipment. So if you wish to donate a brand new instrument, new technology or any other unused item on the wish list please contact us at: amberly@envisiondesigncreate.org

Thank You!

Thank you again for bridging the divide and supporting equality in education because children are our greatest assets.

You will receive the Tax ID via email for your tax write-off once you make a donation.

Perks will be sent out in the Fall 2014 semester! 

Need: Risers, Keyboard, Hand Drums, Small Percussion Instruments

Like to Have: Security – Secure Lockers, Tech Equipment – Projector/ Speakers/ iPad

story:
Our Vision Center Story

The Silicon Valley Vision Center is a 14,000 square foot creative arts and technology facility for the community in San Jose, California.  

Creative Arts, Media Production, Computer Technology, and Health Awareness community classes for under-served kids and youth.   WATCH OUR VIDEO

We believe that every child, and youth should have access to creative arts programs, cutting-edge technology that will benefit their future.  We want to encourage a healthy and wellness lifestyle, as well as, enjoying fun foods!  

 

The Silicon Valley Vision Center after school program, is open to the community.  We are putting together dynamic programs using industry leaders, in each discipline, as instructors, from the Bay Area.  Our schools have struggled to keep creative arts programs vibrant with school budget cuts.  As a community, it is imperative that we shoulder some responsibility of keeping dying programs alive and active in our community.  The Silicon Valley Vision Center's goal is to lead the community in this effort.         

  • We will have recitals, showcasing music and dance achievements. 
  • We will have art contests, and art gallery shows. 
  • We will work with school leaders and community officials, on how we can better serve them and the students in our after-school agenda.  
  • Media screenings will be scheduled of film shorts by our youth 
  • Health and Weight loss goals with an awarding of certificate of achievements
  • Technology Lab to encourage innovation
  • After school tutoring   

          

          (Executive Director Calvin Cook and San Jose Mayoral Candidate Elect Sam Liccardo) WATCH OUR VIDEO

Executive Director Calvin Cook's Community Track Record

The Silicon Valley Vision Center, Executive Director, Calvin Cook has a community track record of giving back and supporting the success of the community.  

  • He spearheaded a food kitchen, that fed the homeless for over 20 years.  
  • Since 1989,  Director Calvin Cook,  has reached out to the poor and the disadvantaged by distributing clothing; such as jackets, hats, socks, shoes, sweatshirts, sleeping bags, and blankets as well as brand new bikes and backpacks until this present day. 
  • He volunteered as chaplain in the City of San Jose, downtown male jail for five years. 
  • As Vice President  of the South Bay Ministers union. For many years, Director Cook operated a drug and rehabilitation home in San Jose, California.  
  • He worked with former San Jose Councilmember Cindy Chavez on a Homeless project.  
  • He spearheaded many wellness fairs in the city parks and outreaches around the city.  
  • As the vice president of Tri-Part institute working the county of Santa Clara. He worked with the black infant health of Santa Clara and help run a program called Creative Health.  A program designed to help prevent obesity and heart disease and to track diabetes and its prevention among those most prone to the those problems. 
  • He has worked closely with the Police Chief in the downtown city parks. 
  • Also gave tours of the city facilities and shelters that provide services for single women in San Jose this project was sponsored by Cindy Chavez

         

Santa Clara County Supervisor Cindy Chavez takes a tour of the Silicon Valley Vision Center with Executive Director Calvin Cook (Music Room).  

He is now setting his sights on supporting the community kids and youth, by opening a community vision center.        

What We Need & What You Get  WATCH OUR VIDEO

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need 15 Apple, Laptops, Mac Book Pro and Creative Software - $19,184
  • We need musical instruments - $6,999
  • We need starter television production gear - mini green-screen studio $68,500
  • Projectors, and projector screens, - $7,747
  • Health & Wellness Resources and Equipment - $25,000
  • Passenger Van to Transport kids - $32,570

What You Get as a Thank You from the Silicon Valley Vision Center? 

      

  (Executive Director Cook gives Mayoral Elect Liccardo the Vision Center Tour)

The Community Impact

The Vision Center expected impact, is to bring greater hope to the community.  Our kids and teens will have, accessible and affordable, options to creativity, technology, media, and health & wellness support.  

  • Deter teenage gang affiliations, crimes, and wrong influences
  • Give a creative outlet for children and youth to express themselves in more positive ways. 
  • Hosts recitals that encourage and celebrate the creative achievements of the students
  • STEM lead in training classes to promote science, technology, engineering, and mathematics taught by industry professionals. 
  • Encourage health and wellness to decrease childhood and teenage obesity. 

Risks & Challenges

Our risks and challenges include:

  • Our Risks: Is the Vision Center being misrepresented; we are not a music school, or creative arts school, computer school, although we plan to facilitate community classes in those areas.  We are a community center in support to our schools, to our families, and to our kids and youth.  It is a center that will provide after school tutoring, computer technology training, media production training, creative arts, and health awareness training.
  • Our Challenges:  We are a start up, and not having the financial resources to move the training sessions forward is a challenge.  This campaign will help us with acquiring the instruments, computers, media gear, and health equipment to mitigate costs. 

Other Ways You Can Help  WATCH OUR VIDEO

  • We understand that you may not be able to help support financially, and it's okay!  Share our link and support us by connecting us with your family, friends, and network.  
  • Use our Indiegogo tools, by clicking the social media links, or send an email to friends and family.  You get the gist!  
  • For those that raise the most dollars, we will give you a Certificate of Appreciation signed by the Executive Director with a picture of our students. 

VISION CENTER DONATION PROCESSING

The Vision Center donations will be held in C/O Golden Altar Ministries non-profit arm.  Donations made to the Vision Center will be, strictly, kept in an account for the Vision Center.  The Non-Profit Vision Center documents have been filed with the State of California and approved, we are awaiting for the official documentation, and will update upon their arrival.  The TAX ID for the Vision Center is: 47-1239946, if you prefer a secondary tax receipt referencing, your donation to the Vision Center that was received by the non-profit arm Golden Altar Ministries, please send us an email through the campaign email messaging center.    

INDIEGOGO DONATION PROCESSING FOR NPOs 

Indiegogo uses a third-party to process donations, called First Giving.  You cannot donate using PayPal, and receive your tax receipt.  Your credit card payment is secure using Indiegogo's First Giving processing, and you will receive an immediate tax receipt for your donation.  Thank you, for your support! 

CONTRIBUTORS: CHECK DONATIONS 

We understand corporate protocols.  If you would like to donate via check, money order, or cash, please contact Carmen Nicolas at the Community Vision Center at 408.993.1962.  Your company will receive a tax receipt for donation, and applicable perks.  If you would like to schedule a tour, Carmen Nicolas, will assist you accordingly.

     disadvantaged by distributing clothing; such as jackets, hats, socks,
     shoes, sweatshirts, sleeping bags, and blankets as well as brand
     new bikes and backpacks until this present day. 
He volunteered as
     chaplain in the City of San Jose, downtown male jail for five years. 
As Vice
     President  of the South Bay Ministers union. For many years, Director
     Cook operated a drug and rehabilitation home in San Jose, California.
      
He worked with
     former San Jose Councilmember Cindy Chavez on a Homeless project.
      
He spearheaded
     many wellness fairs in the city parks and outreaches around the city.
      
As the vice
     president of Tri-Part institute working the county of Santa Clara. He
     worked with the black infant health of Santa Clara and help run a program
     called Creative Health.  A program designed to help prevent obesity
     and heart disease and to track diabetes and its prevention among those
     most prone to the those problems. 
He has worked
     closely with the Police Chief in the downtown city parks. 
Also gave tours
     of the city facilities and shelters that provide services for single women
     in San Jose this project was sponsored by Cindy Chavez


         Santa Clara County Supervisor Cindy Chavez takes a tour of the Silicon Valley Vision Center with Executive Director Calvin Cook (Music Room).  

He
is now setting his sights on supporting the community kids and youth, by
opening a community vision center.        

   What We Need & What You Get  WATCH OUR VIDEO
 
Break
it down for folks in more detail:

We need 15 Apple, Laptops, Mac
     Book Pro and Creative Software - $19,184

We need musical instruments - $6,999

We need starter television
     production gear - mini green-screen studio $68,500

Projectors, and projector
     screens, - $7,747

Health & Wellness Resources
     and Equipment - $25,000

Passenger Van to Transport kids
     - $32,570



What You Get as a Thank You from the Silicon Valley Vision
Center? 


      
  (Executive Director Cook gives Mayoral Elect Liccardo the Vision Center Tour)


The Community Impact The Vision Center expected impact, is to bring greater hope to the community.  Our kids and teens will have, accessible and affordable, options to creativity, technology, media, and health & wellness support.   
Deter teenage gang affiliations, crimes, and wrong influences Give a creative outlet for children and youth to express themselves in more positive ways.  Hosts recitals that encourage and celebrate the creative achievements of the students
STEM lead in training classes to promote science, technology, engineering, and mathematics taught by industry professionals. 
Encourage health and wellness to decrease childhood and teenage obesity.  



  

Risks & Challenges
Our
risks and challenges include:


Our Risks: Is the Vision Center being misrepresented;
     we are not a music school, or creative arts school, computer school, although
     we plan to facilitate community classes in those areas.  We are a community
     center in support to our schools, to our families, and to our kids and
     youth.  It is a center that will provide after school tutoring,
     computer technology training, media production training, creative arts,
     and health awareness training.

Our Challenges:  We are a start up, and not having the financial
     resources to move the training sessions forward is a challenge.  This
     campaign will help us with acquiring the instruments, computers, media
     gear, and health equipment to mitigate costs.  




  
Other Ways You Can Help  WATCH OUR VIDEO

We understand that you may not
     be able to help support financially, and it's okay!  Share our link
     and support us by connecting us with your family, friends, and network.
      
Use our Indiegogo tools, by
     clicking the social media links, or send an email to friends and family.
      You get the gist!  
For those that raise the most
     dollars, we will give you a Certificate of Appreciation signed by the
     Executive Director with a picture of our students. 


VISION CENTER DONATION PROCESSING

The Vision Center donations will be held in C/O Golden Altar
Ministries non-profit arm.  Donations made to the Vision Center will be,
strictly, kept in an account for the Vision Center.  The Non-Profit Vision
Center documents have been filed with the State of California and approved, we
are awaiting for the official documentation, and will update upon their
arrival.  The TAX ID for the Vision Center is: 47-1239946, if you prefer a
secondary tax receipt referencing, your donation to the Vision Center that was received
by the non-profit arm Golden Altar Ministries, please send us an email through
the campaign email messaging center.    
INDIEGOGO DONATION PROCESSING FOR NPOs 
 Indiegogo uses a third-party to process donations, called First Giving.  You cannot donate using PayPal, and receive your tax receipt.  Your credit card payment is secure using Indiegogo's First Giving processing, and you will receive an immediate tax receipt for your donation.  Thank you, for your support! CONTRIBUTORS: CHECK DONATIONS We understand corporate protocols.  If you would like to donate via check, money order, or cash, please contact Carmen Nicolas at the Community Vision Center at 408.993.1962.  Your company will receive a tax receipt for donation, and applicable perks.  If you would like to schedule a tour, Carmen Nicolas, will assist you accordingly.

story:
Introduction

My name is Brandon Peak. Originally from central Pennsylvania, I was led in the spring of 2013 to pack up and move (along with my wife and two daughters) down south to sunny New Port Richey, Florida. In short order, we bought a wonderful home, made great friends, and started to settle in.

A Problem

It didn’t take long for us to begin to notice just how radically different this area is from what we were used to – housing wise. For instance, we saw nice, well kept, well-loved homes right next to run down empty houses with busted windows and overgrown lawns. (Come to find that about 20% of all housing in the city is vacant) Or one side of the street will be clean and attractive while the other side is abandoned and dilapidated. The blight was so widespread and didn’t seem to be limited to one area over another. No neighborhood… no street… is exempt. The next thing I noticed was just how many people rented their living space rather than owning. (One third of all single family homes in the city are renter occupied. This is about double the county average) I wrongly assumed that it must be a “rent-because-it’s-cheaper” climate. In fact it costs MORE to rent here than it does to have a mortgage on a home. Rents are high and many landlords are less than reputable. The more I talked with longtime residents, the more the real problem became clear. Many people want to plant roots in New Port Richey, commit to buying a home, and take some pride in caring for their property – but can’t. Why?

  • Bad credit
  • No down payment savings
  • Poor condition of homes in their price range

It was quickly obvious that this trend of housing, and the negative ripple effect it causes, was not going to correct itself any time soon. Something new needed to be done.

A Solution

I was motivated to really examine what I could bring to the table. What I could do. Steps I could take. Since I work in the field of Architecture as a Project Manager, I was able to draw on a pool of close friends in real estate, construction, insurance, lending, and the like. Through those chats, these notions kept coming back up:

What if there was a way to purchase these blighted properties, renovate, and connect them with people who are struggling with the credit and down payment issues? What if there was a way to set up a program for them to be able to move into the new house and for 12 months, build an escrow account, build credit, and learn a bit of how to care for their property? What if 100% of the profits from one project were put right back into doing more projects? Helping more people? What impact would this make?

What impact would it make? Blight would be transformed into beauty. Neighborhoods would be more desirable. Surrounding property values would improve. Pride in home ownership would be restored. Families could finally plant in the city – and save money on living expenses. True equity would be built. And through it all, a sustainable cycle of improving the city would be born.

317Development

So this is what we’re setting out to do. I’m working to pool all of the resources, friends, consultants, and contacts I have to do exactly what I just described. I’m setting up 317Development to oversee and facilitate the vision:

“Developing high quality home ownership opportunities for individuals and families with a focus on self-sufficiency, neighborhood revitalization, and overall housing sustainability.”

I will be donating all of my time to make this work. This is not an investment angle. This is a natural desire to make a change around me – and a will to do whatever it takes to succeed.

What We Need & What you get

This campaign has been set up to help offset the costs of doing the first project. Your support will go directly towards:

  • Fees to set up 317Development as a legal entity.
  • Purchase down payment and closing costs on a real New Port Richey property.
  • Deposits on renovation costs.

Please keep in mind, that one of the best parts of this effort, is that from just this one project, the seed gets planted to grow many future projects. Your donation will grow into 10… 20… projects in the coming years.

Perks for donating can be seen at the right side of this page – and we really look forward to sharing some of those tokens with you as we work through the inaugural project.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can donate funds. That’s ok. We would still really appreciate your help in:

  • Getting the word out about this campaign. Please share the link to this page with your social media friends and contact lists. Encourage them to come and check out what’s happing in New Port Richey.
  • Staying tuned to our page for updates, new photos and videos. We’ll be posting new information as we go – so please check back often.

Thank you for your support!!

everyone can donate funds. That’s ok. We would still really appreciate your help
in:

     the link to this page with your social media friends and contact lists.

     videos. We’ll be posting new information as we go – so please check back

story:
Camp Power to Be started out as a small program in 2010. In our first year we provided space for 36 children and implemented the camp in an open field

area. Since then we have expanded the program to provide services for youth between the ages of 6 and 18.

This year, we hope to provide our various programs for more than 100 children and youth in the Negril community.

We need your help to make this year a success!

story:
Kaua'i In Need Of Preschools


We can help the children and community on Kaua'i by opening another opportunity for a positive and enriched learning environment while embracing the Hawai'ian values of aloha (compassion & empathy), mālama (to care for & protect), 'ike pono (to know & do what is right), kuleana (take responsibility), & ho'omau (preserve & perputuate)

  • My name is Jennifer Nagle, teacher and mother of 5.
  • Interdisciplinary Early Childhood Education Degree
  • Master's in Special Education
  • Proficient in sign language
  • Proficient in Spanish
  • Highly experienced with children of Autism
  • Preschool math specialist
  • We live on Kaua'i
  • Husband was born on O'ahu

As a teacher and a mother I see the desperate need, there are currently only three preschools in Kilauea, there is no support, no other place for these children to go.  If we rally as a community, we can create a high-quality place and support the working families.  This has a huge impact on our community.




Why This Is So Important


When Gov. Neil Abercrombie signed Senate Bill 2545 in 2012, repealing the junior kindergarten program at the end of the 2013-14 school year, it created a pool of children who, unless conditions change, will fall through the cracks when it comes to early childhood education. 

“There is a shortage of preschools on the island. I’ve never seen it this bad,” said Val Rita, director of A Room to Grow school in Lihue.  “I know in Lihue and Kapaa, in particular, there are a lot of pre-schools with waiting lists. Now that the law has gone into effect, parents are getting desperate. I’m getting a lot of calls from parents of 4 year olds that don’t have any place for their children to go.”

That law, coupled with the age change requirements created by an earlier act compounded the problem. 

Children who turn five years old on or after Aug. 1 this year will need to wait until the 2015-16 school year to enroll in kindergarten. Prior to that bill being signed, children could enter public school if they were at least five years old on or before Dec. 31. 

The age requirements are forcing hundreds of parents to scramble for preschools where they can enroll their children.




A Call for Excellence in Early Childhood Education

Early years are the learning years.  The demand for early childhood care and education programs continues to increase not only in response to the growing demand for out-of-home child care but also in recognition of the critical importance of educational experiences during the early years. Several decades of research clearly demonstrate that high-quality, developmentally appropriate early childhood programs produce short- and long-term positive effects on children's cognitive and social development.

  • All young children deserve excellent early care and education
  • High quality early experiences make a difference in children’s lifelong academic and social success
  • These programs must be accessible to all families
  • Early childhood professionals must have excellent preparation, ongoing professional development, and compensation commensurate with their qualifications and experience
  • Effective early education must be both challenging and appropriate to young children’s ages, individual needs, and culture 
  • Everyone needs to work together to build a successful future for our youngest children



Risks & Challenges

Our nation can and must do better to create opportunities that help all children and families succeed. The time for action is now.

The Hawaiian cultural values of aloha, mālama, and kuleana are an integral part of your child’s preschool learning experience.  Our vision of a community based early education program will work to nurture these values while continuing to provide a learning environment that is safe, educational, culturally-grounded, enjoyable and enriching.

Mahalo Nui Loa!

We understand if can't contribute, no worries.  But that doesn't mean that you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise, children are being denied a preschool education simply because there aren't enough preschools.
  • It's easy use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
My name is George Gordon-Smith, Ph.D. I am Visiting Assistant Professor of English and Disability Studies at Emory University and Founder & Senior Editor of an online personal statement and college admissions essay editing service called EssayCritique. 

As a college professor interested in both English and disability, I notice a lot of disparities between access to education and education resources for people with and without disabilities. Universities and colleges across the country have made great strides in making universities more accessible to people with disabilities (there's still a lot of work to be done, though), but not much has been done to help people with disabilities get into higher education institutions to begin with. High schools are largely unequipped to help students with disabilities navigate the complicated and often difficult college admissions process. That's where my non-profit comes in.

I need $1000 to develop a non-profit organization dedicated to offering the same services my non-disabled clients enjoy at EssayCritique. $500 of the money raised will be dedicated to attorney fees to file my organization as a 501(c)(3), and the remaining $500 will be used to develop and advertise my non-profit website where people with disabilities can access my editing, consulting, and proofreading services for free to help them get into the colleges and even graduate schools of their dreams. 

I am passionate about demonstrating that people with disabilities deserve the same rights as ablebodied Americans, and I want to make sure that people with disabilities have access to the same resources as others when it comes to the difficult and expensive college application process. Help me get more kids with disabilities into our excellent institutions of higher education.

story:
Hi. I'm Mari Smith. I'm a Junior at Leaves of Learning in Cincinnati Ohio.

I love science and someday, I will become an astrophysicist. Recently I was nominated to attend the Congress of Future Science and Technology Leaders being held in Boston this June. I was nominated by former astronaut Buzz Aldrin; and he walked on the moon, so that's pretty cool.

The Congress of Future Science and Technology Leaders, sponsored by the National Academy of Future Scientists and Technologists, is three once-in-a-lifetime days of awe inspiring motivation, excitement, friendship and education.

I will be interacting with:

• Winners of the Nobel Prize

• Award winning young inventors and scientists

• Academic leaders

• Leaders of science and tech

• Scientific futurists

I will get to be mentored by some of the greatest living minds in science – men and women who are literally leading humanity into the 21st century of innovation and discovery.

And afterwards, I will continue to receive mentorship, resources, and direction to help me achieve my goals in the field of science.

This will be a truly transformational experience. But I can't get there on my own.

So I want to ask you if you could help me get to the Congress with a financial gift. I'm hoping to raise around $2000 which would cover attending the Congress, airfare and hotel.

I am very excited about this great opportunity and would love to have you be a part of it.

Thanks!


For more about the Congress, please visit: http://www.scitechleaders.com/

story:
Greetings,

In gratitude, I would like to share a deep aspiration that I hold for myself. This aspiration is to participate in a 200 hour yoga teacher training and become a certified yoga instructor. I believe that completing a 200 hour yoga teacher training program will enhance my ability to be of service to this world, which is my heart's truest desire. My intention is to transmit the tools and teachings of yoga in service of children, babies, prenatal/postnatal women, and for mental health.

Yoga as it relates to:

Children-

From my experience of being a nanny for 9 years I have learned that children have energy and creative expression to invest! My philosophy is that if we can teach young ones how to cultivate the energy of the mind and body and channel that energy into a beneficial practice such as yoga and meditation they will then become empowered to become free thinkers, grounded, clear and focused. Practicing yoga at such a young age has been known to boost self-esteem and confidence and strengthen the mind-body connection. Guided yoga for children/babies has also been shown to stimulate muscle and nerve development. My intention is to offer yoga and meditation to the children that I work with as a creative and physical endeavor.

Prenatal/Postnatal-

My dream of working with prenatal/postnatal women began about 5 years ago. Having been pregnant and experiencing a miscarriage shifted my life in profound ways.It gave me the direction and purpose I need to be an advocate for women. Studies have shown that practicing prenatal yoga has reduced stress and anxiety for the mother and child, providing emotional support, increasing blood and lymph circulation, supporting the physiological process of pregnancy and strengthening the body, thereby decreasing stress on weight-bearing joints. Yoga has been shown to support women in labor by providing techniques such as breathing/ relaxation practices, muscle control, and deepened kinesthetic awareness. Postnatal yoga has been known to decrease soreness and enable a faster recovery, supporting healthy postpartum structural changes, and relieving discomfort from poor alignment and possible strain injuries by strengthening the muscles. My goal is to provide yoga to women with the physical/emotional support that they need in order to have a healthy and stress free pregnancy and labor.

Mental Health-

A recent event that I experienced has guided my passion for yoga in a new direction. This year a very close relative of mine, who suffered from extreme depression, passed away. In life I believe that tragic events take place, and as devastating as they can be, they also have the opportunity to create inspiration for others. Through this life altering event I have found inspiration to integrate yoga and meditation into the lives of those who suffer from mental illness's such as depression, bi-polar disorder, PTSD etc. Yoga has allowed me to cultivate self confidence, self love, a more balanced and harmonious diet, creative expression and the circulation of energy in my physical body. It has changed my life dramatically by relieving stress and anxiety, creating space for "room to breath", and address life's daily challenges with a positive outlook. Coming from a world where mental illness is at an all time high, I would like to introduce yoga for mental health.

The course I wish to attend is a 22 day immersion covering over 30 different topics including, Anatomy and Physiology, Ayurveda, Pre/Post natal and family yoga, Global Healing Meditation, Sanskrit, Mudras and Alignment.The cost of tuition is $4,000 and is certified by Yoga Alliance.Both of my teachers, Molly McLaughlin and Kristen Coyle are experienced registered yoga teachers with over 2,000 hours of teaching. These two skilled and loving teachers have guided my practice and growth in the most beautiful of ways over the past year. To attend this incredible training would be a dream come true, and a blessing that I intend to share with everyone.

Although I am working on securing the funds for this training I need your help to make my dreams become a reality! Your help is so greatly appreciated. Please consider funding my campaign in any way that you can. Even the smallest donation helps!

“Every great dream begins with a dreamer. Always remember, you have within you the strength, the patience, and the passion to reach for the stars to change the world.” - Harriet Tubman

My heart is filled with gratitude to you all.

Blessings and Love.

Molly
story_txt: Greetings,In gratitude, I would like to share a deep aspiration that I hold for myself. This aspiration is to participate in a 200 hour yoga teacher training and become a certified yoga instructor. I believe that completing a 200 hour yoga teacher training program will enhance my ability to be of service to this world, which is my heart's truest desire. My intention is to transmit the tools and teachings of yoga in service of children, babies, prenatal/postnatal women, and for mental health. Yoga as it relates to:Children- From my experience of being a nanny for 9 years I have learned that children have energy and creative expression to invest! My philosophy is that if we can teach young ones how to cultivate the energy of the mind and body and channel that energy into a beneficial practice such as yoga and meditation they will then become empowered to become free thinkers, grounded, clear and focused. Practicing yoga at such a young age has been known to boost self-esteem and confidence and strengthen the mind-body connection. Guided yoga for children/babies has also been shown to stimulate muscle and nerve development. My intention is to offer yoga and meditation to the children that I work with as a creative and physical endeavor. Prenatal/Postnatal-My dream of working with prenatal/postnatal women began about 5 years ago. Having been pregnant and experiencing a miscarriage shifted my life in profound ways.It gave me the direction and purpose I need to be an advocate for women. Studies have shown that practicing prenatal yoga has reduced stress and anxiety for the mother and child, providing emotional support, increasing blood and lymph circulation, supporting the physiological process of pregnancy and strengthening the body, thereby decreasing stress on weight-bearing joints. Yoga has been shown to support women in labor by providing techniques such as breathing/ relaxation practices, muscle control, and deepened kinesthetic awareness. Postnatal yoga has been known to decrease soreness and enable a faster recovery, supporting healthy postpartum structural changes, and relieving discomfort from poor alignment and possible strain injuries by strengthening the muscles. My goal is to provide yoga to women with the physical/emotional support that they need in order to have a healthy and stress free pregnancy and labor. Mental Health- A recent event that I experienced has guided my passion for yoga in a new direction. This year a very close relative of mine, who suffered from extreme depression, passed away. In life I believe that tragic events take place, and as devastating as they can be, they also have the opportunity to create inspiration for others. Through this life altering event I have found inspiration to integrate yoga and meditation into the lives of those who suffer from mental illness's such as depression, bi-polar disorder, PTSD etc. Yoga has allowed me to cultivate self confidence, self love, a more balanced and harmonious diet, creative expression and the circulation of energy in my physical body. It has changed my life dramatically by relieving stress and anxiety, creating space for "room to breath", and address life's daily challenges with a positive outlook. Coming from a world where mental illness is at an all time high, I would like to introduce yoga for mental health. The course I wish to attend is a 22 day immersion covering over 30 different topics including, Anatomy and Physiology, Ayurveda, Pre/Post natal and family yoga, Global Healing Meditation, Sanskrit, Mudras and Alignment.The cost of tuition is $4,000 and is certified by Yoga Alliance.Both of my teachers, Molly McLaughlin  and Kristen Coyle are experienced registered yoga teachers with over 2,000 hours of teaching.  These two skilled and loving teachers have guided my practice and growth in the most beautiful of ways over the past year. To attend this incredible training would be a dream come true, and a blessing that I intend to share with everyone. Although I am working on securing the funds for this training I need your help to make my dreams become a reality! Your help is so greatly appreciated. Please consider funding my campaign in any way that you can. Even the smallest donation helps!“Every great dream begins with a dreamer. Always remember, you have within you the strength, the patience, and the passion to reach for the stars to change the world.” - Harriet TubmanMy heart is filled with gratitude to you all.Blessings and Love.Molly

story:
Hello. my name is Fredrick Davis. I am 41 years old. Between 2003 and 2011 , I had four brain surgeries and a stroke. Upon leaving the hospital in Dec. 2011, the doctor told me that I would be a vegetable or dead within a year. This drove me into despair, I lost my job, home, and vehicle, after almost killing myself through bad choices. In may of 2012,  I moved to Little Rock, Arkansas where I met my pastor and other congregants at Grace Presbyterian church. The love and compassion shown there encouraged me to go back to school and study social work. For fall semester 2014, Arkansas  Rehabilitation paid $1000 towards my tuition and $500 for books leaving me with a balance of $651. Because of my academic accomplishment for the semester (3.33 gpa) and my extra curricular participation,(network for student success- trio-N.F.S.S. chess champion) I have been nominated to be a Student Ambassador for Pulaski Technical College. I' am only eligible provided my fall expenses are paid in full. Then, as an student ambassador my tuition for the spring semester will be covered. Would you please help me? I appreciate any help you are able to contribute so that I can accept this wonderful opportunity.  $651 is what is needed before Jan. 5

For making a contribution, you will receive a copy of my spring semester grades, A personal hand written thank you note, an hour of community service donated in your honor to one of Grace Presbyterian church, Little Rock.

story:
UPDATE: 

Thank you, SO MUCH, everybody for getting us this far. As I write this, the Bow Valley Music Festival is 99% funded.  Any additional contributions will go 50% to student scholarships, so don't stop now! 


STORY:

Those of us who live in the Bow Valley are lucky enough to be surrounded by the grandest landscapes nature can offer, and we take advantage of it.  Youth in our community grow up skiing, snowboarding, climbing, hiking, and all kinds of other activities that most can only dream of doing.  But these activities don’t make a complete childhood, and the arts are woefully underrepresented in our community.  The Bow Valley Music Festival is trying to change that.

I’m Noah Borin, representing the Bow Valley Music Festival.  I have been teaching music for almost a decade and have seen firsthand what this creative outlet can do for children. 

For the past 5 years, we have run on a budget designed to cover costs and continue offering this festival to our community.  Now we are at a crossroads.  It’s time to grow in both size and scope and offer more, but we need your help to make this growth happen.  The Bow Valley Music Festival is unique in our area, and the service it provides our youth in invaluable.  Thank you in advance for your support. 

What We Need & What You Get

The Bow Valley Music Festival is looking at growing in several key areas.  Your $2,500 in contributions will help us do many things.  But first, we need to point out a few things.  First, our board is entirely volunteer-based and we have no staff members.  None of your contributions will go towards wages or honorariums for the BVMF team.  Second, we set our registration prices to be as low as possible in the hopes that nobody is barred from entry because of money.  Our fees are set to cover the normal operating costs of our festival (mostly hiring adjudicators and renting space).  Your contributions will allow us to both expand into our dream festival and keep our registration fees down. 

Provincial Festival Plans

We have joined the Alberta Provincial Music Festival Association (http://www.albertamusicfestival.org/default.aspx).  As part of this group of festivals across Alberta, we can send our best to Edmonton to compete in the Provincial Music Festival in May.  The Youth in our community finally have an artistic goal to strive for – to represent us in Edmonton with the best-of-the-best from around the province. In Edmonton they have a reason to strive to be better, the chance to meet other like-minded students, be rewarded for their years of hard work, and the chance to make a memory they’ll never forget.  These things already exist in sports in our community, but now they can exist in the arts too.  More, we dream of these kids coming home and telling their friends how cool it was to travel and do music!

This doesn't come free.  Joining this group will cost us in terms of membership dues.  If we raise enough money here, we would love to offer financial aid to those students chosen to travel. 

Additionally, joining requires us to adopt new organizational systems to meet provincial regulations.  This is exactly the kind of one-time cost that your contributions here will help us make. 

New Instruments, More Adjudicators

A Music Festival is only as good as its adjudicators.  These charismatic, talented, and knowledgeable people are the cornerstone of our festival.  A good adjudicator makes the difference between not just a good and a bad experience, but a good and a great experience for our participants.

The larger we get, the more adjudicators we need.  We are looking to expand our class offerings into vocals and winds, but this means more adjudicators and we may not have enough entries in the first year to pay their fees.  We cannot afford to “cheap out” on this part of the festival, and committing to extra instruments means committing to this cost especially.  We pay competitive rates with other music festivals, and it will be very difficult for us to take this risk without your contributions here.  We know there are vocalists and wind players in the valley for whom our festival would be a great experience, and we believe they will show up.  We need your help to get over this first hump.

New Festival Programs

Many participants and audience members have, in the past, been disappointed that we did not have a festival program where they could see all the participants, their performance times, learn about our adjudicators, and hear about like-minded people in the community.  This year, we hope to put one of these together to satisfy this demand.  Printing costs are high, however, and none of us have any design experience.  This would be the first thing we would need to pay somebody else to do for us. 

...And If the $2,500 Doesn't Happen?

If we don’t our entire goal, our priorities would be:

1)Fulfill Provincial Obligations and give support to invited students

2)Make new instrument groups available in our festival

3)Make a  Festival Program


The Impact

The Bow Valley Music Festival has already run, successfully, for five years.  This project is about creating a festival as good as any other here in the Bow Valley.  Whether or not this project funds will not change whether or not we have a festival; funding this project allow us to grow into what we all dream it will be. 

The Bow Valley Music Festival is not a competition, but a celebration.  It celebrates the countless hours of hard work by all the performers.  It showcases them, proudly, as musicians and artists.  It puts them in touch with others their age who also love music and want to excel at it.  It celebrates who they are.

It’s easy, here in the Bow Valley, to love sports and outdoor stuff – and that’s great! It’s hard to love music and arts, but we can change that.  With your help, we can make arts cool too.

Risks & Challenges

As I mentioned, the Bow Valley Music Festival will run whether or not we are fully funded here.  We will simply need to assess what we are able to do.  Instead of “all of it”, we will have to piecemeal it.  With no funding, growth will be nearly impossible.  The biggest challenge of all will be staying relevant at our current size and funding amount. 

It is possible that we hire adjudicators for these new instrument groups and nobody shows up.  We have already been spreading the word amongst teachers and community members that we intend to do this, and the response has been positive.  It is impossible to know before registration opens whether or not this will be an opportunity that the community capitalizes on, but we are out there doing what we can so that, at least, nobody can say “I didn’t know”. 

Rest assured that your contribution will be used.  100% of our funding goes directly to programming, and it will be no different here.  We will use every dollar contributed to better our festival. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for reading this far! If you have, I certainly hope you’ve been moved to contribute. If you can’t, help us get the word out! Let locals know, link it on your Facebook page, or whatever else! We can’t thank you enough for anything you do.

story:
A Little Bit About Us

Our school is the only Jewish School in Volgograd, Russia. We help Jewish kids grow up with Jewish values and education, so even in a city like Volgograd our ancient tradition would not be forgotten.

We are also one of the best schools in town thanks to our great team of educators and staff, many of whom hold different awards for achievements in the field of education.

But all these people are on the edge of losing their jobs... Our students may have to transfer to a regular public schools where no Jewish tradition and value is taught and antisemitism might be an issue...

Our challenge

For over ten years we have been renting two buildings from the local government and we have put lots of effort into making these old Soviet Union buildings into a beautiful school with many spaces designated for various activities.

Many Russian parents cannot afford a private school, and we are eternally grateful to the Or Avner Foundation for funding our school thus far and giving an opportunity to every Jewish child in our area to be educated in a Jewish way, to preserve our tradition and eventually pass it on to the next generation. 

Now with the new law passed by the government, the rent for all non-profits is much higher than before and our usual funding cannot cover it... This law has brought an expense of extra $5000 into our monthly budget, and in a city like Volgograd it is very hard to afford. 

Our Goal

We have decided to try and raise that amount for a 10 months period with hopes that in less than 10 months we will be able to achieve our small victory and bring the rent back down.

We hope that with your help our school will not shut down and we will continue to shape young Jewish minds and souls into adults with a strong Jewish identity and moral values - adults that will become the future of our nation.

Your contribution is an investment into the future of Jewish people.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot help us financially, you can spread the word among people you know and with your effort more people will find out about us and our struggle.

story:
In the early 1990s, Dr. Michael Shermer catapulted to prominence as a “skeptic” by attacking, vilifying, and lying about Jewish Holocaust revisionist David Cole. While befriending Cole and profiting from the association (Cole even got Shermer his first national TV gig), Shermer took every opportunity to stab Cole in the back every chance he got. Even after Cole left the revisionist scene, Shermer continued to attack him in two separate books.

Shermer claims to despise "true believers," but when it comes to Holocaust revisionism, the "skeptic" inside of him runs for cover, and the "true believer" emerges. 

Shermer’s disgraceful behavior is detailed in Cole’s book, “Republican Party Animal,” in which transcripts of recorded conversations with Shermer reveal his admissions that he lied about and defamed Cole. Shermer went so far as to have his lawyers threaten Cole’s publisher with legal action to prevent the book from being released. Cole and his publisher sent Shermer and his lawyers running, retreating from their threat, and promising no more trouble as they scurried away like mice.

As far as Cole is concerned, there are no more hard feelings. Time for dinner! Yes, Dr. Mikey Shermer has announced a private dinner party and wine tasting event at his “cliff-side home” on January 25th, with special guest Bill Nye the Science Guy, which can be attended by anyone for a donation of a mere $500.

What better opportunity for David and Mikey to bury the 22-year-old hatchet? Dinner, wine, and the side of a cliff...a perfect recipe for reconciliation. The only problem is, David is ethically troubled by the notion of paying $500 to a man who defamed him and helped fuel the lynch-mob that nearly cost him his life.

Therefore, David is asking YOUR help to raise the $500 to pay his way into his old foe's cliff-side abode for a night of food, wine, and rationalism. Admit it – you know this will be interesting. Perhaps even a small disaster. If fifty of you put in $10 each, the dream can live.

So let’s stand tall on the wings of our dreams! Donate today (all donations will be refunded should Dr. Shermer refuse entry to David Cole, or should mudslides cause Dr. Shermer to regret buying a cliff-side home in Southern California).

If Cole raises MORE than $500, he’ll take a guest!

See you cliff-side, Doc Shermer!

story:
Short Summary

Assata Shakur (2001) once said that we must either tell our own story or our oppressors will do it for us.  Four teacher intellectuals, G Reyes, Karen Salazar, J.R. Arimboanga, and Josette Neal De Stanton, from ARISE High School in East Oakland have been selected to present their critical participant research at the Ethnography in Education Forum at the University of Pennsylvania in February 2015.  Essentially, this research is grounded in our own struggle to empower our ourselves to act as highly educated, humanizing, critically conscious, intellectual, and reflective leaders within our community.  

There is already numerous work that says what teachers should know and be able to do.  However, there's not much that comprehensively articulates the conditions for how they should know and do those things.  Working with a commitment to social justice is one thing.  But how do like-minded educators in the same context work to nurture their own and each other's cultural responsiveness and technical competence?  This is what we are trying to collaboratively understand.  We are not outsiders trying to understand some else's innovations and struggles.  We are inside our own community and context trying to gain critical insight into what we do so that we could learn how to become better while influencing others committed to urban education, because frankly, as Dr. Patrick Camangian (2013) asserted, our lives depend on it. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to travel from East Oakland, California to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania on February 26, 2015 and return back on February 28.  Conference fees have already been generously covered by ARISE High School, but we need to raise our own funds for airfare and hotel accommodations.  We are estimating the cost per person is $875, totaling $3500 for all four of us.  If we do not reach our goal, all the funds raised will still go towards the journey, and we will have to evaluate the reality of the remaining dollars coming from our own shallow pockets.  

Should you be able to donate to our important cause, we will share some of the key insights from our research findings by sending you a link to an upcoming mini documentary that we will create by June 2015.  

The Impact

Highly acclaimed educator, Gloria Ladson-Billings (1999) noted that the most current innovations in schools are not typically written about and communicated, because the people doing the work are busy doing the work.  We are trying to counter that reality, because we truly believe we have a lot to offer to the greater urban education community, particularly teacher preparation programs, urban teacher pipeline programs, teacher development providers, and of course, schools.  At the same time, we are not arrogant to say that we have all the answers, so we know that through our systematic research, we will be able to problematize, name, and better understand our current work in order to determine how to intentionally improve for our students.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't financially contribute to our cause, you can still help.  Please spread the word to your family, friends, and colleagues.  You can also set us up to use your timeshare in Philadelphia, if you have one.  If you have experience publishing your work, we would love to get your advice and expertise for making our findings more widely accessible.
story_txt:
Short Summary
 Assata Shakur (2001) once said that we must either tell our own story or our oppressors will do it for us.  Four teacher intellectuals, G Reyes, Karen Salazar, J.R. Arimboanga, and Josette Neal De Stanton, from ARISE High School in East Oakland have been selected to present their critical participant research at the Ethnography in Education Forum at the University of Pennsylvania in February 2015.  Essentially, this research is grounded in our own struggle to empower our ourselves to act as highly educated, humanizing, critically conscious, intellectual, and reflective leaders within our community.  
There is already numerous work that says what teachers should know and be able to do.  However, there's not much that comprehensively articulates the conditions for how they should know and do those things.  Working with a commitment to social justice is one thing.  But how do like-minded educators in the same context work to nurture their own and each other's cultural responsiveness and technical competence?  This is what we are trying to collaboratively understand.  We are not outsiders trying to understand some else's innovations and struggles.  We are inside our own community and context trying to gain critical insight into what we do so that we could learn how to become better while influencing others committed to urban education, because frankly, as Dr. Patrick Camangian (2013) asserted, our lives depend on it. 
   What We Need & What You Get We need to travel from East Oakland, California to Philadelphia, Pennsylvania on February 26, 2015 and return back on February 28.  Conference fees have already been generously covered by ARISE High School, but we need to raise our own funds for airfare and hotel accommodations.  We are estimating the cost per person is $875, totaling $3500 for all four of us.  If we do not reach our goal, all the funds raised will still go towards the journey, and we will have to evaluate the reality of the remaining dollars coming from our own shallow pockets.  
Should you be able to donate to our important cause, we will share some of the key insights from our research findings by sending you a link to an upcoming mini documentary that we will create by June 2015.  
    The Impact Highly acclaimed educator, Gloria Ladson-Billings (1999) noted that the most current innovations in schools are not typically written about and communicated, because the people doing the work are busy doing the work.  We are trying to counter that reality, because we truly believe we have a lot to offer to the greater urban education community, particularly teacher preparation programs, urban teacher pipeline programs, teacher development providers, and of course, schools.  At the same time, we are not arrogant to say that we have all the answers, so we know that through our systematic research, we will be able to problematize, name, and better understand our current work in order to determine how to intentionally improve for our students.


    Other Ways You Can Help Even if you can't financially contribute to our cause, you can still help.  Please spread the word to your family, friends, and colleagues.  You can also set us up to use your timeshare in Philadelphia, if you have one.  If you have experience publishing your work, we would love to get your advice and expertise for making our findings more widely accessible.

story:
As we celebrated our 100th Anzac Day anniversary on 25th April in Australia where the Prime minister gave his speech in the remembrance of the soldiers who fought bravely and also lost their lives. One particular part where "Mr Abbott recounted how Australian diggers experienced that legendary bravery and generosity firsthand ‘when they fought alongside the Gurkhas at Gallipoli a hundred years ago’"(http://www.southasia.com.au/?p=992) was enough to say.

11:56 am the land of Gurkhas, Nepal was hit by a 7.9 magnitude earthquake, killing over 3500, over 6000 injured, and many more missing and buried under the rubbles of the collapsed buildings. Many villages were destroyed completely, leaving no one to survive. Although the neighboring countries did have the effect of the earthquake , there weren' as effected as Nepal.

People have lost their family members, relatives, friends and loved ones,  their home, their belongings and they have no where to go. The lucky ones, whose houses were still in one piece are still not able to settle back, because of the after shocks, which has been more than 100 in numbers in just these few days. Researchers have said this may last for weeks, till it calms down completely.

People are on streets, parks and other open areas with almost no food and water. Medical aid is running low in hospitals with dead bodies piled on one another. 

Countries like India, Israel, China, America, Britain , Singapore, Pakistan were very quick to respond and send their rescue teams with medicine, food , water and mobile hospitals. Even after all this there are many other places where the only way remaining to get to them is by air, where people are not even able to receive any aid.

In our attempt with this fund raising campaign we are trying to at least fulfill the immediate essential supply(food,water & shelter) for the victims. Any and every cent will make a difference. We are in contact with various organisations and looking into where the funds should go for its utilization to its best possible way.

We request you all to please donate any amount less or more which will still count as a contribution.

 #prayfornepal

story:
Ma famille et les amis ont été confrontés au problème de tremblement de terre de 7,9 magnitude, c'est une catastrophe au Népal. Nous suivons à la télévision que beaucoup de pays et d'organisations aident le Népal mais mes amis me disent qu'ils n'ont pas obtenu de secours encore. Ils n'ont pas assez d'eau et de nourriture. il n'y a pas d'électricité. Leurs maisons sont détruites ou en très mauvais état. Ils auront besoin de reconstruire ou réparer leurs maisons afin qu'ils puissent reprendre leur vie normale. Alors, je tiens à les aider personnellement en fournissant des fonds qui seront recueillis auprès de vous, afin de leur envoyer vos dons au Népal.

Soyez assuré que 100% de la somme recueillie ira à ma famille et mes amis.

Aidons et prions pour le Népal Merci.


My family and friends have been facing a problem because of a 7.9 magnitude disaster earthquake in Nepal. We have been watching TV that a lot of countries and organizations are helping Nepal but my friends told me that they hadn't got any services still. They don't have enought clean water and good food. There is no electricity. Their houses are in very bad condition. They need to repair their houses and restart their normal lives. Hence, I would like to help them personally by providing the fund which will be collected from all of you, by sending them in Nepal.

Be sure that 100% of the collected amount will go to my family and friends.


Lets help and pray for Nepal thank you.

story:
What is Papalotes?

Papalotes is a community project run by parents and teachers in Puerto Escondido, Mexico. We believe there is a huge need to offer an alternative education model in Mexico since the traditional model is failing. That is why we have taken the initiative to create a different option, turning a tiny part of the world into a friendlier place.

The project currently offers a Waldorf-inspired activities for nearly 30 students, ages 2 to 10 from a variety of backgrounds including local kids with full scholarships. The project is 100% non-profit and legally established. Living in one of the poorest states in Mexico, we firmly believe that if we want to create a better world, we need to educate our children differently.


What do we want?

We think that children have the right to develop healthily in body, mind and spirit. We teach them how to deal with their emotions, to respect nature and their fellow beings. We let them explore the world freely, inspire them to question themselves and to learn things that make sense to them in their lives. Although academics are important, there is so much more to life than that! We are encouraging critical reasoning and the social and artistic sensitivity that form free and morally responsible individuals. Children naturally love learning, and we support ours to become learners for life. Educating our young ones for an uncertain future that we cannot predict but that we can create, we want our students to keep their human side intact. That is why we foster them to be compassionate and empathetic; share and work as a team.


We are pioneers

We are pioneers planting new seeds: loving and caring teachers; free children; committed parents. We have created a project where exploration and experimentation is the base, and where it is alright to make mistakes because it is the mistakes that make us learn and grow. We are pioneers of a project that respects the rhythm of each child, where play is part of the learning process. More than pioneers of an alternative system, we are pioneers of education as the only true alternative for a positive change in the world.


Success = Growth

Due to our success in the first three years of the project we have outgrown our current campus, but thankfully we have found the perfect building that suits our pedagogical and philosophical needs, with a beautiful garden where the children can explore freely and safely.


Do you want to be part of creating a healthier world?

This is how you can help!

  1. By donating money, you will ensure that we can buy the materials needed in order to adapt the new house. It has been unused for several years, and we need to paint it, fix the bathrooms, install light fixtures, curtains and shelves inside and a fence will have to be put in place outside to guarantee the safety of the kids. (The material needed include cleaning supplied, 300 liters of paint, 10 shelves, 15 curtains, 100 fence posts and fence as well as a structure to provide shade during play-time outside. 
  2. If you happen to live in Puerto Escondido we can accept donations of building materials, and if you’re a handy-person you can join us during the summer of 2015 as we wash, paint, build and install to prepare the new campus.
If we manage to raise more money than what we´re asking for, we would also be able to invest in ergonomic tables and chairs for our older children and build a nice playground for all of our kids.

Perks!

  • By donating 10 USD you will receive a virtual thank you and an up-date on how our project has evolved.
  • By donating 25 USD you will also receive a small piece of art made by the children.
  • By donating 100 USD you will get a calendar for 2016 with beautiful pictures from our project.
  • By donating 1000 USD you get the right to name one of our classrooms.


Who’s behind all this?

Short answer: About 20 families living in Puerto Escondido, wanting a better education for their kids, plus four teachers and our friends and families. We organize and run the project as well as events and campaigns to raise funds.

Parents and children: last day at the old  house.

Our marvelous teacher team: Anais, Irene, Manuela and Alicia.


The non-profit organization Papalotes Puerto Escondido A.C. is composed of Rebecka Koritz, Ramón Cuevas, Alicia Maawad and Leo Utskot.


Facts about Papalotes Puerto Escondido

  • Our project started up in 201
  • The project is run by the parents and the teachers.
  • The tuition fees cover the basic needs such as rent, teacher salaries, insurance and materials.
  • We are a registered non-profit organization
  • All of our teachers are on an ongoing teacher training within the Waldorf pedagogy.
  • We offer scholarships to families that can´t afford our tuition fees. They represent 15% of all the families.

The project is run by the parents and the teachers.
The tuition fees cover the basic needs such as rent, teacher salaries, insurance and materials.
