story:
Last year, on a long flight (is there any other kind?!) from London to Sydney, I overheard children complaining to their parents – We’re bored! Where are we going? When will we get there? What will we do when we get there?

As you might imagine, the parents didn’t have the answers ... well, none that would satisfy their children, who really needed - some might say deserved - answers.

An idea started to form in my head and I set about combining my business, marketing and writing experience with my passion for travel.

Bound Round was born.

At Bound Round we've begun creating interactive travel guide apps for children.  Yes, there are plenty of popular travel guides already – but the significant gap in the market is for interactive travel guides that are designed for children but are relevant to both children AND parents. 

What are my qualifications in this area? Well, it turns out I have had to draw on all my experience to bring this idea to life – my skills in marketing strategy and business development, writing and project management. Add to this my passion for travel and my interest in children’s entertainment and education, and my fabulously supportive network of friends and colleagues, and in 12 months, Bound Round has gone from concept to reality.

Bound Round apps entertain and educate children who are lucky enough to travel, but we also want to help those who are not so fortunate. So we've partnered with not-for-profit Room to Read, and will donate $0.05 from every Bound Round app sold to help them educate children in need.

What makes Bound Round fun and educational for kids?

We think that children should be given every opportunity to explore and experience the different cultures the world has to offer. Simple black and white text doesn’t exactly engage children or help parents plan their holiday.

Bound Round apps use stories, photos, videos and games to help kids uncover all the fun things to do while holidaying in a particular location. This gives them more of a vote in holiday planning, resulting in a more enjoyable trip for the entire family.

With Bound Round, children will be able to preview their destination and flag the places they think sound like fun, while the parents will have access to exclusive discounts for the venues the children rated on their ‘to do’ list.  

So kids, it means you can...

  • Play Bound Round before you arrive at your destination and find out what's going to be fun to do there.
  • Highlight the places you like so you can show your parents (before they drag you to loads of places that sound boring).
  • Unlock cool games, videos and extra information for each place you read about... and play them any time, even without an Internet connection!
  • Use your Bound Round travel journal to keep track of all the amazing stuff you do on your trip, and even print it out to show your friends and family when you get home.
  • Get stamps in your Bound Round passport for each place you end up visiting.
  • Hunt for your Bound Round animal tour guide – like Kook the kookaburra -  while visiting any of the locations mentioned in the story and take your photo with them so you can show everyone you've been there
  • Send e-postcards to your friends and family while you’re away so they can see all the fun you’re having!

And what about the adults?

Bound Round isn’t just for the kids –there are real benefits for parents, too.

  • Bound Round guides entertain children on long journeys, giving you at least 45min of 'quiet time'.
  • Once downloaded, Bound Round can be used without an Internet connection, making it perfect for the car and the plane.
  • The apps keep track of the places your kids think sound fun, so you can build them into your itinerary.
  • We know the last thing you want is to do MORE research! So, Bound Round has an ‘Info for Adults’ section that reduces your workload by providing things like opening hours, contact details, locations and, where possible, a link to the venue's website, so you can find out all the information you need before you go there.

But wait! There’s more!

  • We know that holidays can be expensive, so we’ve negotiated some great Bound Round discounts for the destinations your kids have been reading about and want to visit. 
  • The apps also capture feedback from other adult Bound Round users about specific destinations and the Bound Round app itself.

If you’ll pardon the pun, we believe we’re creating well-rounded apps that will help make your family holidays even more enjoyable!

So why the campaign?

Creating Bound Round is very exciting, and we've got an amazing team working to launch Sydney, our first location, in November.

So far I've funded the app entirely on my own.  My team has put in thousands of hours for free to get the first Bound Round Sydney guide to where it is ... ready to launch in time for the Christmas holiday season!

But there's still a lot of work to do.... because let's face it, kids travel to loads of places other than Sydney!

The $30,000 we want to raise with this campaign will allow us to finish building Bound Round Sydney.  The money raised here will help cover the costs of development... which on their own are $30,000.

By supporting this campaign you'll be helping develop our future destinations ... you’ll have a vote in our creative process and the opportunity to feature in the app yourself! Getting involved at this stage of development also means you'll get access to some pretty cool perks that won’t be available in the future ... like a personalised, signed postcard from our award-winning photographer, Fiona Riches.

And for only $50, you'll get an invitation to the Bound Round launch party where you'll get to meet the creative team, and the kids will get to experience some of the fun things that are included in Bound Round Sydney.

Check out the other rewards listed over on the right side of this page!

What can I do to help if I can't pledge?

Spreading the word about Bound Round is just as helpful as contributing cash.  So, if you can't pledge money, we'd love you to share our story!  There are lots of ways you can do that:

  • Tell people about this campaign... email, drop it into conversation, broadcast it on the radio or TV, we don’t mind how, we'd just love as many people as possible to hear about Bound Round!
  • Visit our website by searching for Bound Round in Google (searching is better than typing in the link) and while you’re there, please sign up to our e-newsletter so you don't miss out on all our exciting news
  • Like our Bound Round page on Facebook & share our news with your friends
  • Follow us on Twitter & join our conversations

Thank you for getting behind Bound Round! We believe this project will help parents and children have better conversations about their holidays – and a better time while they’re away. Not to mention all that new-found quiet time for parents while the kids are being simultaneously entertained and educated by Bound Round.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT. WE REALLY APPRECIATE IT AND ARE SUPER EXCITED ABOUT SHARING OUR FIRST LOCATION WITH YOU IN A FEW SHORT MONTHS!

Thanks, Janeece

Well, it turns out I have had to draw on all my experience to bring this idea to life – my skills in marketing strategy and business development, writing and project management. Add to this my passion for travel and my interest in children’s entertainment and education, and my fabulously supportive network of friends and colleagues, and in 12 months, Bound Round has gone from concept to reality.
Bound Round apps entertain and educate children who are lucky enough to travel, but we also want to help those who are not so fortunate. So we've partnered with not-for-profit Room to Read, and will donate $0.05 from every Bound Round app sold to help them educate children in need.
What makes Bound Round fun and educational for kids?
We think that children should be given every opportunity to explore and experience the different cultures the world has to offer. Simple black and white text doesn’t exactly engage children or help parents plan their holiday.
Bound Round apps use stories, photos, videos and games to help kids uncover all the fun things to do while holidaying in a particular location. This gives them more of a vote in holiday planning, resulting in a more enjoyable trip for the entire family.
With Bound Round, children will be able to preview their destination and flag the places they think sound like fun, while the parents will have access to exclusive discounts for the venues the children rated on their ‘to do’ list.  
So kids, it means you can...

Play Bound Round before you arrive at your destination and find out what's going to be fun to do there.
Highlight the places you like so you can show your parents (before they drag you to loads of places that sound boring).
Unlock cool games, videos and extra information for each place you read about... and play them any time, even without an Internet connection!
Use your Bound Round travel journal to keep track of all the amazing stuff you do on your trip, and even print it out to show your friends and family when you get home.
Get stamps in your Bound Round passport for each place you end up visiting.
Hunt for your Bound Round animal tour guide – like Kook the kookaburra -  while visiting any of the locations mentioned in the story and take your photo with them so you can show everyone you've been there
Send e-postcards to your friends and family while you’re away so they can see all the fun you’re having!
And what about the adults?
Bound Round isn’t just for the kids –there are real benefits for parents, too.

Bound Round guides entertain children on long journeys, giving you at least 45min of 'quiet time'.
Once downloaded, Bound Round can be used without an Internet connection, making it perfect for the car and the plane.
The apps keep track of the places your kids think sound fun, so you can build them into your itinerary.
We know the last thing you want is to do MORE research! So, Bound Round has an ‘Info for Adults’ section that reduces your workload by providing things like opening hours, contact details, locations and, where possible, a link to the venue's website, so you can find out all the information you need before you go there.
But wait! There’s more!

We know that holidays can be expensive, so we’ve negotiated some great Bound Round discounts for the destinations your kids have been reading about and want to visit. 
The apps also capture feedback from other adult Bound Round users about specific destinations and the Bound Round app itself.
If you’ll pardon the pun, we believe we’re creating well-rounded apps that will help make your family holidays even more enjoyable!
So why the campaign?
Creating Bound Round is very exciting, and we've got an amazing team working to launch Sydney, our first location, in November.
So far I've funded the app entirely on my own.  My team has put in thousands of hours for free to get the first Bound Round Sydney guide to where it is ... ready to launch in time for the Christmas holiday season!
But there's still a lot of work to do.... because let's face it, kids travel to loads of places other than Sydney!
The $30,000 we want to raise with this campaign will allow us to finish building Bound Round Sydney.  The money raised here will help cover the costs of development... which on their own are $30,000.
By supporting this campaign you'll be helping develop our future destinations ... you’ll have a vote in our creative process and the opportunity to feature in the app yourself! Getting involved at this stage of development also means you'll get access to some pretty cool perks that won’t be available in the future ... like a personalised, signed postcard from our award-winning photographer, Fiona Riches.
And for only $50, you'll get an invitation to the Bound Round launch party where you'll get to meet the creative team, and the kids will get to experience some of the fun things that are included in Bound Round Sydney.
Check out the other rewards listed over on the right side of this page!
What can I do to help if I can't pledge?
Spreading the word about Bound Round is just as helpful as contributing cash.  So, if you can't pledge money, we'd love you to share our story!  There are lots of ways you can do that:

Tell people about this campaign... email, drop it into conversation, broadcast it on the radio or TV, we don’t mind how, we'd just love as many people as possible to hear about Bound Round!
Visit our website by searching for Bound Round in Google (searching is better than typing in the link) and while you’re there, please sign up to our e-newsletter so you don't miss out on all our exciting news
Like our Bound Round page on Facebook & share our news with your friends
Follow us on Twitter & join our conversations
Thank you for getting behind Bound Round! We believe this project will help parents and children have better conversations about their holidays – and a better time while they’re away. Not to mention all that new-found quiet time for parents while the kids are being simultaneously entertained and educated by Bound Round.
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT. WE REALLY APPRECIATE IT AND ARE SUPER EXCITED ABOUT SHARING OUR FIRST LOCATION WITH YOU IN A FEW SHORT MONTHS!
Thanks, Janeece

story:
Your donation will buy the supplies needed to reach all the schools and groups that would otherwise not have the opportunity to learn and engage their communities. The complex issues surrounding genocide and mass atrocities need all our voices, commitment and progressive action in effort to bring both political and community attention. Empowering our own communities to stand one million strong against the needless violence.


Take a stand.
Help us cover the National Mall in Washington, D.C .with 1,000,000 handmade bones. It will represent a visible petition against the humanitarian crises due to ongoing conflict happening in places like the Democratic Republic of Congo and Somalia. It also symbolizes a mass grave, honoring lives lost and showing our solidarity with those who have survived mass conflict.


Make a bone.
It’s a powerful symbol of what unites us - our shared humanity. It will remind us that we belong to each other, and that we stand in solidarity with victims and survivors of mass atrocities. Every bone you make generates $1 for CARE, a leading humanitarian organization —up to $500,000.


Together, Rebuild!
We are tapping into people’s creativity to make a tangible difference in the lives of those living in the DRC and Somalia.
We are working to give ongoing tragedies—from intractable poverty and famine, to war and conflict—an emotional presence and a powerful voice. We are working to unite people and provide the means to both demand attention and raise support for our peers in the DRC and Somalia.


Why Bones?
Bones are universal. Bones are strong. Bones symbolize our common humanity. And, they are poignant reminders of unnecessary and preventable loss. They are the physical evidence that individuals, people, ever existed. The bone laying is the intersection of art and activism, of education and action, and it will represent the mass graves that are the result of ongoing genocides/atrocities/conflict as well as remind us that we belong to each other.

story:
Our Story

We just shipped 32 donated surfboards, that were all-volunteer repaired, to our youth after-school program on Siargao Island, Philippines. Help us meet our shipment this coming November and facilitate the documenting of our story to spread awareness of our program so we can get college scholarships for these kids. Balikbayod-Returning Wave promotes education 1st through the love of surfing. Our home base is in San Francisco, California and we are a project of the non-profit San Francisco Filipino Cultural Center. Balikbayod-Returning Wave's motivation is based on our "Love of Surfing" and sharing that love to others, especially to children living in one of the world's top surf spots, inspiring them to get educated through the love of surfing. Giving them a chance to make something of themselves so they can give back to their own community as we have with ours.

The Impact

The documenting of our trip meeting the kids and the surfboards will be telling a much larger story, how our group has evolved from a few people to many and how we started with 4 surfboards and just recently sent our first overseas shipment of 32 surfboards, all through money raised by art sale fundraisers and donated art from amazing people. We want to help these kids past elementary and high school and get them to college! Help us film this documentary to we can bring this story to a larger audience and rally more support. If our campaign is not successful, we'll still get as much filming done as we can, but it probably won't be as complete as we would like lacking a director.

What We Need & What You Get

We are volunteers and are paying our own transportation costs (airfare, food and lodging). We would like to bring our surfboard repair kahuna, Jin An Wong, who has labored all summer long repairing the donated surfboards and teaching free surf lessons to our volunteers. He is also an animation art director and is volunteering to direct the documentary short film we will be capturing. He is an integral part of our team and we don't want him left behind when we go this November. We need $3000 to cover his transportation and lodging costs. If we don't reach the goal of $3000, Jin An has opted to contribute the money raised to the rest of the group's transportation costs and filming costs.


Donations of $100 or more get a free surf lesson from Jin An

Donations of $50 get a Kelly's Cove Reunion T-shirt from Jin An

Donations of $10 get a 4x5' Balikbayod Thank You Photograph


www.IsabellaRecords.com will donate 50% of it's commission to Balikbayod to help support your mission.  From November 7, to December 31, 2011 anyone who buy's item's on this Website from Big Name Brand Company's www.IsabellaRecords.com will donate 50% of it's commission to help Balikbayod reach their goal and beyond.  The Acero Giles Family is in a new History book called, Filipinos in San Francisco, anyone could purchase this book at a discount price on my Website and the next fundraiser event that Balikbayod has, myself and other Giles members will come down and autograph the books from everyone who has purchased this book.


*If Jin An doesn't come with us, then the prizes of the surf lesson and t-shirts are null and void, so please help us spread the word so you can get your prizes!!!


Other Ways You Can Help

1) Share this link with your friends to get to the prize

2) If you don't want to support this campaign but still want to give to the organization, you can make a donation here http://balikbayod.wordpress.com/

3) Volunteer with us at our fundraisers, repair parties or with our program in the Philippines

4) Donate FCS style fins, leashes and repairable surfboards (no surfboard turned away)

5) Network or collaborate with us to reach our goals

story:
Our Story

Welcome My Fiends !  

The Best Fiends Forever show!!  The above video is only a taste of what we have in the works and is mainly a sneak peek of whats to come and we wanted to make it fun, but we need your help!  Think of the Muppets or Sesame Street, but with some edge and some Batitude ;)  This is a project thats been in the making for many of years and started from ideas written in a notebook. Its now finally brought to life after putting the pieces together and the Fiends coming all together to make it happen . But it's in need of some support to help produce the shows in all areas. Your pledges will help us create sets, set pieces, props and so much more that we are in need of to continue. We are creating more characters along with storyboards for future episodes and thinking of great ways to entertain and most importantly teach the youth of today some much needed old fashion lessons in a very fun and very cool way.

We are in need of some decent audio equipment to record with, a lot of other gear that is too much to list, but it all will help us get the job done. Along with all the equipment and supplies, a lot of time and money is put into set building and cast. There is so much that goes into each episode and we would really love your help!

Please make a pledge and become a part of history!  We really hope to surpass our goal to continue to bring you bigger and better episodes. Every penny goes into the shows we create, and we set a small goal to at least help us get started. Thanks so much and stay tuned !!

xo- Best Fiends Forever

http://www.facebook.com/BestFiendsForever

 

The Impact

As we stated above, we really feel that the values of the Golden Age are almost completely lost in the youth of today. We want to make it fun and mix in great lessons to help teach kids and the fans of those values, traditions, music, arts and entertaining material that is educating.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We stated this above as well to make it short and sweet. Every penny goes into the projects and each production we shoot. If we do not reach our goal, it still helps us to keep going, nothing is lost. The more pledges we get will help us to continue and make each episode bigger and better, and we hope to surpass our goal as this project is never ending.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

PLEASE and we cannot stress this enough, PLEASE share this with your friends and your family to help us continue. Use the share link and post it in all your Social Media outlets and help us!  We love you for any and all of your support !!!

story:
My Name is Xavier Fux and I have been involved with Permaculture since 2006. I own a company called Green Beat Solutions which provides consulting in sustainabililty, and we are currently trying to create a Permaculture Institute in Tulum, Mexico.

During October and November of 2011, my wife Melanie and I led a permaculture project in Congo, where we helped a community of 500 Pygmies become self sustainable:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8-_YUQfHTKE

http://www.congoproject2011.blogspot.mx/

During this amazing experience, we learned that it is sometimes better to provide help closer to one's own country; after all, charity begins at home... With just the money it cost us to buy the airplane tickets to Africa, we could have started a project here in Mexico.

Sadly, there are too many places in the world that need help, nutritious food, and education. So why not start nearby, within our own local communities and friends?

The Green Beat Permaculture Institute of Tulum will provide a center for local and Mayan peoples to get training and education in fields such as organic, bio-intensive agriculture, rain water catchment systems, residual water treatments, garbage management, soil creation by composting and mulching, and business skills in order to sell their surplus in local co-ops and to local restaurants and hotels.

Our goal is twofold: one, to have a center where courses, workshops, and guided tours can educate children and adults from Tulum and nearby Mayan communities  on the importance of eating healthy, organic, nutrient-packed foods as well as learning how to grow it without the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers which are polluting the fragile underground river system that flows beneath the Yucatan Peninsula. The mission is to empower them so they can sell their produce to local restaurants and hotels.

Severe droughts in the past three years have prevented local Mayans from cultivating their stapled corn, squash and bean crops. Famined farmers need to learn rain water catchment systems in order to secure enough of this precious liquid for their crops to grow. Children need to learn that industrial agriculture, mismanaged cattle and GMO's are rapidly turning our planet into a dry, arid desert, and that it is possible to cultivate nutrient rich food in small areas through intensive, organic, friendly methods that save energy and resources and produce high yields.

The funding will go towards building the huts where we will host the workshops and courses. We will also use the money to build a volunteer/woofing facility where we will be able to sponsor up to 10 people to trade their work in exchange for food, shelter and educational experience.  This they will take back to their communities, where they will be able to implement what they learned and build a better, healthier life for themselves.

Funding will directly assist the building of:

  1. Woofing & Volunteer cabins
  2. Classroom and teaching hut
  3. Buying tools for students: machetes, shovels, spades, etc
If we dont reach the goal of $6000 USD, rest assure that your money will go towards the building of infrastructure for this project and that we will not stop working until the campus is finished and operational. 
 
Your contribution will contribute not only to the local Mayan community who will have a center to learn, grow and sell their produce, but to the world at large, since we will also be providing a model that can be replicated in many rural areas of the world, while at the same time helping the tourism industry by providing fresh, organic produce grown by local communities for local restaurants and hotels.
 
Please check out our videos and blog on the Congo Project to see that our work and funds reach their goals!!
 

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8-_YUQfHTKE

http://www.congoproject2011.blogspot.mx/
 
 
Perks: You will receive different bonuses and perks if you decide to fund us: from a free 5 kg basket of fresh produce, or a free visit to a mayan community that has benefited from this program, to a 1 week, free internship at our farm.

Please help us plant seeds of Love, and we shall harvest sweet fruits....

story:
Dec 15 Update: Our Founder & Executive Director, Amber Stott, was named "40 Under 40" by the Sacramento Business Journal! 

Saving the World with Broccoli Smiles

When you eat broccoli, do you smile? We do! So do the kids in our food literacy classes – many for the first time.

Only 25% of Americans eat their daily fruits and veggies. And this number is even lower for people in low-income, high-risk neighborhoods like the one our kids live in.

That’s a big reason why 38% percent of kids in California are obese. They have adult diseases like high blood pressure and diabetes – and they’re carrying these problems into adulthood. 

This makes us sad.

So we're changing that – saving the world with broccoli smiles.

We teach food literacy: understanding the impact of food on your health, your community and your environment. And we make it fun.

You can learn all about it on our website: http://californiafoodliteracy.org/.

The kids in our classes are learning how to cook, about nutrition, to eat right and enjoy healthy food. Our founder, Amber Stott, even dresses up like a giant carrot. We’re not interested in scaring people about bad food. We want people to feel inspired to eat good food.

This makes us smile. We hope it makes you smile too.

Our nonprofit has accomplished a lot in its first year!

Amber Stott founded California Food Literacy Center in 2011 to combat childhood obesity and teach people about the important connections between our food, health, environment and community.

Our movement is growing! In just one year we:

  • Created a 13-week food literacy curriculum and taught food literacy to 100 low-income kids every week
  • Developed and shared a healthy recipe each week on our website so everyone in our community can eat healthy, simple meals
  • Passed a resolution declaring every September Food Literacy Month in the state of California
  • Joined the Food System Collaborative & Sacramento Hunger Coalition to work on collaborative solutions to our region's food problems
  • And so... much... more!

Here's what the kids have to say...

After our classes, a whopping 70% of kids request broccoli and celery from their parents. 88% know how to read a nutrition label. 100% of them know how to cook a healthy snack.

100% of them now eat their vegetables. 

Here's what they tell us they've learned:

  • “Apples are better for you than jelly.” ~ 5th grader

  • “Jelly is not a fruit.” ~ Kindergartner 

  • “Potatoes have no fat and chips have 10 grams of fat.” ~2nd grader

  • “Broccoli has no fat!” ~ 1st grader

  • “I learned that fruits and vegetables have seasons.” ~1st grader

Just imagine what we'll do next year! 

Help us raise $11,000 by January 1! Your gift is tax deductible.

We know how to stretch a dollar! With just $11,000, we can accomplish all this:

  • Teach 100 K-5th grade kids a weekly food literacy lesson
  • Write 33 weeks of food literacy curriculum
  • Train 15 community volunteers to become food literacy teachers through our 10-week Food Literacy Academy
  • Bring food literacy education to more schools and nonprofits
  • Cook a weekly healthy dish, and share the recipe with you on our website
  • Report on weekly food news to keep you informed

And that's just the beginning... 

*Cue veggie cartwheels and applause for your donation! 

We're a 501c3 nonprofit. Your gift is tax deductible. Our tax ID#: 45-3973268.

You can learn more about our work at our website: http://californiafoodliteracy.org/
story_txt:
Dec 15 Update: Our Founder & Executive Director, Amber Stott, was named "40 Under 40" by the Sacramento Business Journal! 
Saving the World with Broccoli Smiles
When you eat broccoli, do you smile? We do! So do the kids in our food literacy classes – many for the first time.
Only 25% of Americans eat their daily fruits and veggies. And this number is even lower for people in low-income, high-risk neighborhoods like the one our kids live in.
That’s a big reason why 38% percent of kids in California are obese. They have adult diseases like high blood pressure and diabetes – and they’re carrying these problems into adulthood. 
This makes us sad.
So we're changing that – saving the world with broccoli smiles.
We teach food literacy: understanding the impact of food on your health, your community and your environment. And we make it fun.
You can learn all about it on our website: http://californiafoodliteracy.org/.
The kids in our classes are learning how to cook, about nutrition, to eat right and enjoy healthy food. Our founder, Amber Stott, even dresses up like a giant carrot. We’re not interested in scaring people about bad food. We want people to feel inspired to eat good food.
This makes us smile. We hope it makes you smile too.

Our nonprofit has accomplished a lot in its first year!
Amber Stott founded California Food Literacy Center in 2011 to combat childhood obesity and teach people about the important connections between our food, health, environment and community.
Our movement is growing! In just one year we:

Created a 13-week food literacy curriculum and taught food literacy to 100 low-income kids every week
Developed and shared a healthy recipe each week on our website so everyone in our community can eat healthy, simple meals
Passed a resolution declaring every September Food Literacy Month in the state of California
Joined the Food System Collaborative & Sacramento Hunger Coalition to work on collaborative solutions to our region's food problems
And so... much... more!

Here's what the kids have to say...
After our classes, a whopping 70% of kids request broccoli and celery from their parents. 88% know how to read a nutrition label. 100% of them know how to cook a healthy snack.
100% of them now eat their vegetables. 
Here's what they tell us they've learned:


“Apples are better for you than jelly.” ~ 5th grader


“Jelly is not a fruit.” ~ Kindergartner 


“Potatoes have no fat and chips have 10 grams of fat.” ~2nd grader


“Broccoli has no fat!” ~ 1st grader


“I learned that fruits and vegetables have seasons.” ~1st grader


Just imagine what we'll do next year! 
Help us raise $11,000 by January 1! Your gift is tax deductible.

We know how to stretch a dollar! With just $11,000, we can accomplish all this:



Teach 100 K-5th grade kids a weekly food literacy lesson
Write 33 weeks of food literacy curriculum
Train 15 community volunteers to become food literacy teachers through our 10-week Food Literacy Academy
Bring food literacy education to more schools and nonprofits
Cook a weekly healthy dish, and share the recipe with you on our website
Report on weekly food news to keep you informed

And that's just the beginning... 
*Cue veggie cartwheels and applause for your donation! 
We're a 501c3 nonprofit. Your gift is tax deductible. Our tax ID#: 45-3973268.
You can learn more about our work at our website: http://californiafoodliteracy.org/

story:
Short Summary

Studentloanjustice.Org is a grassroots, citizens organization dedicated to returning standard consumer protections to student loans.  The group was started in March, 2005, and has focused primarily on research, media outreach, and grassroots lobbying initiatives.

The group and its members have been featured on 60 Minutes, 20/20, The News Hour, CNBC, and many other television programs,  print media including the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Washington Post, Fortune Magazine, The Chronicle of Higher Education, and many others as well as numerous radio and internet broadcasts. The group is also featured in a documentary airing and screening in Fall, 2010.

The group was credited as the inspiration for The Student Borrower Bill of Rights, and has broken numerous news items in the press with its research findings regarding conflicts of interest in the student loan system, Student Debt levels, Default Rates, corporate lobbying, and other areas.

Group Founder Alan Collinge has written numerous articles, and editorials on the topic, and also published The Student Loan Scam in 2009 (Beacon Press).  
 
 
What We Need & What You Get

Since our inception, we have struggled fighting for student loan justice.  Specifically, we are fighting for the return of standard bankruptcy protections, refinancing rights, and other standard consumer protections to all student loans.  It is clear that no one in Washington DC is fighting for the citizen's interests on this issue.  This is why the problem has become so bad, and why we exist.
We have, to this point, been self financed through our membership, and this has proven difficult given the size of our task with Congress.

We are currently seeking $3500 to pay for travel and lodging for 3-4 people to go to Washington D.C. to correct the massive dis- and misinformation that has been showered upon Congress by the student loan industry.  Our belief is that when Congress has the true facts, they will do the right thing, and pass legislation that meets our requirements for student loan justice.  We have already raised about half of the total trip cost of $6500

The Impact

While no one wishes to file for bankruptcy for any reason, not having this (and other standard protections) has caused predatory lending behavior, led directly to astonishing increases in college tuition, resulted in inexcusably bad government oversight, criminal lending behavior, and academic waste and unchecked spending... all on the backs of the students...both rich and poor. Please see our argument at the website, and read the articles posted on the main page to understand the problem, and read some of our member's stories to understand the harm this has done to ordinary, decent citizens.
 
By achieving our goal, the system will once again be reoriented such that all of these problems will begin to right themselves.  This will benefit ALL students, rich or poor.  It will also re-stabilize the lending system, which currently is certain to suffer the same fate as the subprime home mortgage system- or worse- if nothing is done.
 
Our Budget is below.  Thank you for your support.
 
 

         SLJ Budget for Trip to D.C.    


     Item                               Description                             Cost


1.  Travel                         3 people (airfare)                      $1,800

2.  Housing                 3 bdr apartment (1 month)             $1,700

3.  Fixed costs            local rent/utilities cost (2 month)    $1,650

4.  Food                     3 people @ $15/day  (1 month)      $1,350
                                                                                              

    Total                                                                       $6,500

story:
Help us create the next wave of American engineers, scientists, and mathematicians! 

We will give teachers accessible lessons with downloadable videos they can use to engage their students and master the most challenging STEM subjects.

For the past 10 years, middle schoolers have been craving a champion of math and science to look up to in the 21st century. Bill Nye the Science Guy took engaging curriculum material TO THA NEXT LEVEL, but unfortunately, writing a song about DNA set to TLC's "Waterfalls" is a bit outdated in 2012. Additionally, with the sheer amount of time and energy it takes to prepare effective and technologically-inspired lesson plans, teachers across the States are overworked and overwhelmed. But with rigorous standards, American students are falling behind - dangerously behind. Currently 50% of America's middle schoolers (as well as 91% of African-Americans and 87% of Latinos) are not proficient in math by the 8th grade. 

I want to alleviate the current climate with a website centering around DR. MADD: 21st Century Madam of Math Mayhem and Science Style. She's a little eccentric, but she loves running experiments, creating music videos, and most of all, educating students on the specifics of math, science, and technology. She also supports the creation of standards-based, downloadable curriculum and instructional materials. 

Along with two other Harvard Graduate School of Education students - my partner "Mathman," AKA math teacher Lybroan and tech expert Frank - I will utilize your donations and put them towards developing a platform that provides "edutainment" content aligned to standards. 

Your donations will go towards:

1) Camera and Sound Equipment - so we've got what we need to drop beats and get good footage!

2) Web Hosting and a Domain Name - so we have a space to launch our site!

3) Monetary Compensation for our Curriculum Developers - many of whom will be teachers!

4) Publicity Materials - to get the Dr. MADD name out there!

Together, we can create that spark of innovation in education - with a little crazy and a lot of fun! By enabling us to make the Adventures of Dr. MADD come alive, you help us close the STEM achievement gap and bring the joy of math and science back to America's classrooms, teachers, and students. Help us create the next wave of American engineers, scientists, and mathematicians!

___________________________________________________________

The pictures below show the back and front of Dr. MADD t-shirts for backers!

 
Front of T-shirt with Red and Black Imagery
 
 
Back of T-shirt with Black Text

story:
MOMAS is a volunteer organization working in San Quentin prison that teaches future parolees the practical skills they need for life on the outside. The program is uniquely positioned for success because it is a collaboration between former program participants and outside instructors.The curriculum is designed to help our students find work, connect with job training and apprenticeship programs, manage their personal finances, and understand the basics of investment and business planning.

We are beginning a new 12 week course and need to raise $700 for textbooks and other printed materials. Over 50 prisoners are signed up for the current course so we are turning to our friends and supporters to help us make sure they get the materials they need. We continue to see a steady increase in interest in MOMAS as more graduates complete the program and talk about their experience with friends and colleagues. With your assistance we can continue to provide the incarcerated men of San Quentin the training they need to successfully reenter society.

We are always looking for people with financial, entrepreneurial and HR backgrounds who would be interested in helping teach and/or develop material for our course. The rewards for this work are hard to describe. You will never find a group of people who are more appreciative of your help and expertise. Our students know the odds are heavily stacked against them once they leave prison, but every one of them is dedicated to changing his life and doing whatever it takes to find adequate housing and work. Every time one of students gets a job it's a win not only for the ex-offender, but also for society. By participating in MOMAS you will be helping to increase neighborhood safety and lower California's budget busting prison costs.

story:
Making a Difference, Honoring a Star

The Johnny Ray Foundation is a not-for-profit 501 (C)((3)organization that was established in 2010 to honor the memory of a young man who showed extraordinary talent in baseball. Johnny Ray was an amazing son, student, baseball player, brother, friend, and individual. On the night of October 24, 2009, his life was taken that would forever impact the lives of those he left behind.

The Johnny Ray Foundation provides academic scholarships to young men and women experiencing financial hardships trying to attend private high schools on Staten Island.  The Foundations's mission is to assist those with complex circumstances by covering a portion of their annual tuition. With this assistance, these students will be able to get individualized attention that is associated with that institution and enable them to excel.  

The foundation is in honor of Johnny Ray.  He lived a short life of only sixteen years, but left his mark on and off the ball field. His spirit remains among us and we wish to keep it alive through presenting others with financial assistance through the foundation's scholarship program


Johnny Ray Foundation

98 Tanglewood Drive

Staten Island NY 10308

(917) 299-9211


"We Play As Many, But Pray As One"

story:
Biased Textbook History Shaping the Ideological Fabric of Our Societies

Biased Textbook History, taught as a set of facts to children in their formative years, in the absence of contrasting narratives breeds a culture of unquestioning conformance and unchecked intolerance which manifests in a variety of forms, the worst of which is the violence that we see in the world around us today.

School going kids as young as grade 6 are bombarded with utterly bizarre information through government mandated textbooks. To showcase just a few such examples:

The grade 8 textbook published by 'Gujrat Center for Educational Research' (GCERT), alludes to the creation of 'Islamic Islamabad' with its capital in 'Khyber Ghat'  pushed into the Hindukush mountain ranges. 


Leveraging the modern day stigma against the terms 'Islam' and the concept of mountain ranges, the text paints a narrative where kids will over time associate the concept of Pakistan over this constructed caricature of a neo-terrorist state.

“They (non-vegetarians) easily cheat, tell lies, they forget promises, they are dishonest and tell bad words, steal, fight and turn to violence and commit sex crimes.”

This is an excerpt from a grade 6 government board textbook in India demonizing people who eat meat using popularly denounced stereotypes. These blatantly biased nuances set the societal tone on these topics making tolerance as one of the more impossible choices amidst mass manipulation.

“(The Indian map should include) ‘countries like Pakistan, Afghanistan, Nepal, Bhutan, Tibet, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka and Burma’ (as it’s all a) ‘part of Akhand Bharat… Undivided India is the truth, divided India is a lie. Division of India is unnatural and it can be united again…’”

This excerpt, from the book 'Tejomay Bharat' (Shining India), attempts to undermine the very existence of the neighboring countries.


“Gandhi was basically an extremist Hindu politician with highly pro-Hindu approach to politics. Due to Gandhi’s non-cooperation movement Quaid-e-Azam re- signed from the Congress in 1920”

The term Hindu has acquired a negative connotation in Pakistan. Through repeated use of the term, M. K. Gandhi, as a personality, is painted in an anti-Muslim light while omitting most details regarding his philosophy on non-violence struggle in the Pakistan Studies book titled ‘Making of Pakistan’.

These examples merely constitute the tip of the iceberg in the context of the extent of bias and misinformation that is embedded in textbooks and fed to our future generations.

A large part of our national identity stems from our sense of history and culture that are deeply rooted in the land and in the legacy of the region’s ancient civilizations. Religion has also played a big part in making us what we are today.

The distortion of historical narratives has in turn played a quintessential role in manipulating our sense of self. Imagine for a minute that you aren’t aware of M.K. Gandhi’s reputation. Imagine that you were starting fresh, learning about the sub-continent’s history. What sort of an image of M.K. Gandhi would be formed in your mind? Or how would you view Pakistan if you grew up thinking its called 'Islamic Islamabad' or that it really should've been a part of India. Or, as a present day Pakistani, how would you view yourself in this tale, tracing your ancestral past?

These aren’t isolated examples and neither is this limited to one side. History, in textbooks, in countries that have a conflict in their past, is filled with polarized narratives shaping the ideological fabric of our future generations.  While there is no magic that can reverse generations worth of conditioning, but in order to at least start the process, we've launched THE HISTORY PROJECT.


We Need Your Help to Empower Your Future Generations by Helping Us Create and Spread The History Project Materials

We’re a young bunch of students and professionals from a variety of nationalities and we believe that the absence of alternate narratives from history education breeds a myopic worldview amongst our future generations. Our future generation is taught history as a set of facts, filled with bias and stereotypes. This biased narratives forms the foundation of our society’s identity adulterated with a victim syndrome leading to intolerance towards differential perspectives.


Your contribution will help us empower over a million young minds (across India / Pakistan) with the ability to identify and question biases in textbook historical narratives used to form national ideologies based on intolerance and de-humanization of the ‘enemy’.

Our next book is a series of essays on six prominent personalities from Indo-Pak history and how their characters have been painted and their contributions skewed in textbook history narratives from both sides of the border.

Building on our original approach by leveraging feedback received from professors from Harvard, Brown, Stanford and Williams, the second volume incorporates in-page provocative questions that proactively help students distinguish between facts, opinions and reasoned conclusions. 


We need $40,000 to publish and launch the second in the series of THP books. While the first book was powered by an army of volunteers, the overwhelming response has made us realize the value in our approach and the potential for changing the way the world teaches history to our future generations.

In an attempt to have an even greater impact and a wider outreach, we want to build a professional product by hiring professional researchers, editors, illustrator and book-layout staff to work on the second book and do it professionally full-time.

India and Pakistan being a demographic where technology hasn’t reached remote areas, it is quintessential that we publish hard copies to reach masses. In case we don’t meet our fundraising goals, we’ll still go ahead and publish the e-book and target the fewer populations that does have access to technology.

Mind you, when talking about countries like India and Pakistan, combined, we’re talking about roughly a quarter of the population on the planet and even if we manage to change a tiny fraction of that number, we’re still talking a massive outreach and change.

Theory of Change

A more tolerant world; is it a future that we all dream of? Wouldn’t we all want our children to be a part of that? And how can The History Project make that happen?

The children of today are the leaders of tomorrow. For better or for worse, they’ll be the ones curating what the next century entails. Lack of access to the other side of the historical story and the manifestation of socio-political bias in history textbooks taught to impressionable minds ends up stereotyping the ideological fabric of our future generations.


The History Project researches history textbooks, and places narratives of a trans-national, shared history side by side, to highlight the commonality of our past, and the contrast in its perception. We introduce questions to highlight embedded biases and activities geared towards understanding competing perspectives. Lastly, we supplement our materials with illustrations to make it more engaging for our readership.

Essentially, The History Project empowers our future generations by introducing them to powerful concepts of multiplicity of narratives of history and the fact that history always comes with the narrator’s bias.

Begotten out of a midnight all-that-is-wrong-with-the-planet conversation, a self-funded personal initiative with a limited vision of a one-off book and a soft launch turned into an overwhelming viral story which featured collaborative presentations by prominent media entities around the world such as WSJ, Times of India and The Hindu.

BBC

http://goo.gl/rQnjFu

NPR

http://goo.gl/jMCVRa

WNYC

http://goo.gl/n7ISt5

The Hindu

http://goo.gl/CQyOd6


However, in all of this, the most rewarding aspect was the influence that it had on the students who responded to the idea by displaying a genuine curiosity. By the end of some of our presentations, we had students throwing stinging questions at us including questions like, ‘if Pakistan was such a great thing, why are there more muslims in India than Pakistan’ and even ‘Is there a God?’.

With zero marketing budget (and without any additional push), the idea continued to spread. We were approached by prominent entities such as Ashoka, Yale-NUS and Brown University who wanted to learn more about what we’re doing. We were also invited to give presentations at prestigious institutions such as Harvard, Brown, Williams and Duke. Simply put, THP is shaping our future for the better and this is your opportunity to become a part of it.


Risks & Challenges

The History Project is attempting to reverse the systematic engineering of biased national narratives breeding specific brands of patriotism. Juxtaposition of contrasting narratives and taking them to students, while it doesn’t disprove one narrative or the other, it establishes undeniably the reality that history, is not a set of facts and is rather a narrative adulterated with the narrator’s bias (deliberate or otherwise).

Understandably, the initiative fails to score a lot of points with the governments and stands the risk of interference from agencies, in case we grow noticeably big. That said, our resolve is that thats a bridge we’ll cross once we get there.

Secondly, India and Pakistan have less than 30% of their populations living in developed areas. Education dissemination through formal schooling systems is itself a massive problem in the not developed parts of the two countries making outreach a massive challenge.

However, just like any third world country that has failed to create an education system to cater to 100% of the population, there are two types of entities that step in to fill the gap. The private institutions that serve the elite and the NGOs that spread out far and wide to try and reach the unserved parts.


Having personally worked in the development section for 14 years, we have good relations with NGOs that have vast networks across the two countries. Our resolve is to partner with these NGOs, fund train-the-trainer workshops and penetrate the 70% under served population through these NGOs.


Spread the Word. Help us Change the way our future generations learn about their past?

 

Can't donate but love the idea and have a few moments to invest - perfect:

1) Update your cover photo

download from here:

http://goo.gl/vnARVTLet your social circle know that you've had #enoughwithbiasedhistory

2) Email us your selfie-video saying the aforementioned phrase.

Email us at support@thehistory-project.org and we'll put it up on our website.

3) Tweet

"My name is MY-NAME. I'm from HOME-COUNTRY. And I've had #enoughwithbiased history"

Pakistan’.These examples merely constitute the tip of the 
iceberg in the context of the extent of bias and misinformation that is 
embedded in textbooks and fed to our future generations.A large part of our national identity stems from our sense of history and culture that are deeply rooted in the land and in the legacy of the region’s ancient civilizations. Religion has also played a big part in making us what we are today.The distortion of historical narratives has in turn played a quintessential role in manipulating our sense of self. Imagine for a minute that you aren’t aware of M.K. Gandhi’s reputation. 
Imagine that you were starting fresh, learning about the sub-continent’s
 history. What sort of an image of M.K. Gandhi would be formed in your 
mind? Or how would you view Pakistan if you grew up thinking its called 'Islamic Islamabad' or that it really should've been a part of India. Or, as a present day Pakistani, how would you view yourself in this 
tale, tracing your ancestral past?These aren’t isolated examples 
and neither is this limited to one side. History, in textbooks, in 
countries that have a conflict in their past, is filled with polarized 
narratives shaping the ideological fabric of our future generations.  While there is no magic that can reverse generations worth of conditioning, but in order to at least start the process, we've launched THE HISTORY PROJECT.We Need Your Help to Empower Your Future Generations by Helping Us Create and Spread The History Project MaterialsWe’re a young bunch of students and professionals from a variety of 
nationalities and we believe that the absence of alternate narratives 
from history education breeds a myopic worldview amongst our future 
generations. Our future generation is taught history as a set of facts, 
filled with bias and stereotypes. This biased narratives forms the 
foundation of our society’s identity adulterated with a victim syndrome 
leading to intolerance towards differential perspectives. Your
 contribution will help us empower over a million young minds (across 
India / Pakistan) with the ability to identify and question biases in 
textbook historical narratives used to form national ideologies based on
 intolerance and de-humanization of the ‘enemy’. Our next book is a series of essays on six prominent personalities from Indo-Pak history and how their characters have been painted and their contributions skewed in textbook history narratives from both sides of the border. Building on our original approach by leveraging feedback received from professors from Harvard, Brown, Stanford and Williams, the second volume incorporates in-page provocative questions that proactively help students distinguish between facts, opinions and reasoned conclusions.  We need $40,000 to publish and launch the second in the series of THP books. While the first book was powered by an army of volunteers, the overwhelming response has made us realize the value in our approach and the potential for changing the way the world teaches history to our future generations. In an attempt to have an even greater impact and a wider outreach, we want to build a professional product by hiring professional researchers, editors, illustrator and book-layout staff to work on the second book and do it professionally full-time.India and Pakistan being a demographic where technology hasn’t reached remote areas, it is quintessential that we publish hard copies to reach masses. In case we don’t meet our fundraising goals, we’ll still go ahead and publish the e-book and target the fewer populations that does have access to technology. Mind you, when talking about countries like India and Pakistan, combined, we’re talking about roughly a quarter of the population on the planet and even if we manage to change a tiny fraction of that number, we’re still talking a massive outreach and change. Theory of ChangeA more tolerant world; is it a future that we all dream of? Wouldn’t we all want our children to be a part of that? And how can The History Project make that happen?The children of today are the leaders of tomorrow. For better or for worse, they’ll be the ones curating what the next century entails. Lack of access to the other side of the historical story and the manifestation of socio-political bias in history textbooks taught to impressionable minds ends up stereotyping the ideological fabric of our future generations. The History Project researches history textbooks, and places narratives of a trans-national, shared history side by side, to highlight the commonality of our past, and the contrast in its perception. We introduce questions to highlight embedded biases and activities geared towards understanding competing perspectives. Lastly, we supplement our materials with illustrations to make it more engaging for our readership.Essentially, The History Project empowers our future generations by introducing them to powerful concepts of multiplicity of narratives of history and the fact that history always comes with the narrator’s bias. Begotten out of a midnight all-that-is-wrong-with-the-planet conversation, a self-funded personal initiative with a limited vision of a one-off book and a soft launch turned into an overwhelming viral story which featured collaborative presentations by prominent media entities around the world such as WSJ, Times of India and The Hindu.BBChttp://goo.gl/rQnjFuNPR http://goo.gl/jMCVRaWNYChttp://goo.gl/n7ISt5The Hinduhttp://goo.gl/CQyOd6However, in all of this, the most rewarding aspect was the influence that it had on the students who responded to the idea by displaying a genuine curiosity. By the end of some of our presentations, we had students throwing stinging questions at us including questions like, ‘if Pakistan was such a great thing, why are there more muslims in India than Pakistan’ and even ‘Is there a God?’.With zero marketing budget (and without any additional push), the idea continued to spread. We were approached by prominent entities such as Ashoka, Yale-NUS and Brown University who wanted to learn more about what we’re doing. We were also invited to give presentations at prestigious institutions such as Harvard, Brown, Williams and Duke. Simply put, THP is shaping our future for the better and this is your opportunity to become a part of it.Risks & ChallengesThe History Project is attempting to reverse the systematic engineering of biased national narratives breeding specific brands of patriotism. Juxtaposition of contrasting narratives and taking them to students, while it doesn’t disprove one narrative or the other, it establishes undeniably the reality that history, is not a set of facts and is rather a narrative adulterated with the narrator’s bias (deliberate or otherwise). Understandably, the initiative fails to score a lot of points with the governments and stands the risk of interference from agencies, in case we grow noticeably big. That said, our resolve is that thats a bridge we’ll cross once we get there. Secondly, India and Pakistan have less than 30% of their populations living in developed areas. Education dissemination through formal schooling systems is itself a massive problem in the not developed parts of the two countries making outreach a massive challenge. However, just like any third world country that has failed to create an education system to cater to 100% of the population, there are two types of entities that step in to fill the gap. The private institutions that serve the elite and the NGOs that spread out far and wide to try and reach the unserved parts. Having personally worked in the development section for 14 years, we have good relations with NGOs that have vast networks across the two countries. Our resolve is to partner with these NGOs, fund train-the-trainer workshops and penetrate the 70% under served population through these NGOs.Spread the Word. Help us Change the way our future generations learn about their past? Can't donate but love the idea and have a few moments to invest - perfect:1) Update your cover photodownload from here: http://goo.gl/vnARVTLet your social circle know that you've had #enoughwithbiasedhistory2) Email us your selfie-video saying the aforementioned phrase. Email us at support@thehistory-project.org and we'll put it up on our website. 3) Tweet "My name is MY-NAME. I'm from HOME-COUNTRY. And I've had #enoughwithbiased history"

story:
Prologue

Amanda led a simple life in a small Bellingham, Washington condo with her husband James, two cats and one bunny named Bunnerz. She was a writer, and during the times that she was procrastinating from her writing (which was most of the time) she enjoyed riding her bike, growing vegetables in a very small patch of dirt, and thinking up clever ways to earn money for the few extra things in life that would make her most happy. The budget was pretty tight, since she was still not a best-selling author, and she had about $20,000 in medical debts looming over her.

Aside from some health issues (which she didn't like to use to get pity) and those pesky debts, life was pretty good. Amanda had learned to find happiness in the little things of day-to-day life. She figured if she could be happy sitting on her tiny patio on a sunny day, listening to the wind breezing through the cottonwood leaves, and watching Bunnerz crunch on a stalk of parsley, that she was leading a pretty fulfilled life. No matter what might come tomorrow, if today was a good day, then she felt like she had done a good job with the time she had been allotted on this earth.

What she hadn't been expecting was an alien invasion, especially not right before her 40th birthday!

Chapter One

Amanda sat on the weathered bench, under the shade of a "Walmart-special" patio umbrella. The umbrella tilted awkwardly because it was cheap, and meant to be paired with a table for additional support. But there wasn't any room on the patio, or in the budget for both. 

Suddenly, there was a horrendous roar overhead, but Amanda didn't look up. She was used to airplanes coming in to the Bellingham airport. The roar was going on for a bit longer than usual. Bunnerz was standing on her hind legs, ears erect. Amanda cooed at the startled bunny. "Don't worry Bun, it's just a plane."

But the noise didn't stop, and then the sky grew dark. Amanda peeked out from under her patio umbrella. The sun was gone, swallowed by the blackness of an enormous round Frisbee shape. A Frisbee even a giant would have trouble tossing! It obliterated half the sky. And she could see tiny dots floating down from it. 

"Oh my God. What is that?" Part of her wanted to run screaming, but as usual when there was an emergency, she slipped into calm, clinical mode. Maybe it was her writers' brain, or maybe it was because she had lost her adrenal glands to a surgery before she turned 21, but she never panicked in a crisis. Sometimes she panicked for ridiculous things, but not in the usual circumstances when other people were panicking.

And people were panicking. She heard screams and shouts from road, and from some of her neighbor's houses. She just squinted up at the sky trying to figure out what the little dots were.

When they got close enough to make out clearly, her first thought was: "Boy those alien robots look really familiar, I could swear I have seen them before, like in some really awesome British Sci-Fi series on TV." But she dismissed the thought, because TV shows were fiction, of course. Not to mention, as a writer, she was sensitive to intellectual property stuff and didn't want to violate anyone's rights by stray thoughts, especially if she wrote the story down one day. So she settled on thinking of them as alien robots.

She opened the patio door and shooed the bunny inside. Bunnerz was terrified enough that for once she did not argue or lead Amanda on a merry chase. She hopped inside and went straight to her cage. Amanda snapped the cage door closed before running back outside. No sense having to deal with an alien invasion and chewed speaker wires.

As she stepped back out onto the patio robots with shiny metal dome heads and blocky bodies with no visible legs were slowly descending toward the ground with hover thrusters. There was one at each of her neighbor's homes, and one landing square on her patio. 

"Hey!" she shouted as the force of his thrusters blew her umbrella off its base. Without thinking, she grabbed the nearest object, an empty cooler. She gripped it by the handle and swung it with all her might at the robot's single eyepiece sticking out of its dome. The lens shattered and the robot spun in circles.

"Error, error, error!" It screamed in a voice that sounded like it was gargling water and speaking at the same time.

"That's what you get when you mess with my umbrella you digital defect!" She threw the cooler at it's head and then rammed the robot with her shoulder, toppling it over. 

Another hovering robot detached from its route and swung in her direction.

"Desist human!" It also screamed in the same voice as the one she had attacked. These robots seemed to only have one voice setting--overkill. 

Amanda didn't stick around to wait for it to arrive. Her neighbors were being herded out of their houses under guard. She was about to be wrangled with them. She dashed back into the house. Her cats were nowhere to be seen, probably hiding. Her husband James was sleeping upstairs, maybe she could get to him before--she heard a crash and a shout as an alien robot smashed through the window upstairs. No! James was captured. 

Bunnerz looked up at her from the cage. Amanda knew what she had to do. She had to run. She had to find some way to defeat the invaders so she could save her husband and her pets. It was the only way.

The only thing she could think of was Canada. She had always figured, in her more fanciful flights of things to worry about, that if the US was invaded she was close enough to jump across the border back to her homeland of Canada--a country invaders might not think it was worthwhile attacking. This wasn't exactly the kind of invasion she had imagined. But maybe her logic would be sound.

And then she had another thought. If there is any way Amanda was going to figure out a way to defeat these invading alien robots, it was going to be by using her skills as a writer, and her mightiest weapon, indeed, her imagination. But first she needed to hone those skills to razor sharpness. 

Just her luck, the Surrey International Writers Conference was hosted across the border in Canada every year. If there were one place she could train to defeat the aliens, it would be there. 

To be Continued...

Join us next time to see if Amanda makes it to the Surrey International Writers Conference and if she learns the skills she needs to defeat the alien robots! 

More about Amanda and her quest...and how you can help!

I am Amanda June Hagarty: writer and all-round nice person. I am hoping to raise money so I can go to the Surrey International Writers Conference. I have devised this crafty ploy to enlist your help in that because it is a big expense. I don't need  it, like a person needs a new kidney or something, so don't feel like you have to donate to my cause. But I really really want to go. And it is my birthday coming up on June 17th, so if you know me and were planning on giving me a lil something for my birthday, this is a nice lil something!

I need to buy my conference ticket before the prices go up on June 30th. The tickets are currently $559 so I am setting my goal as $600. That doesn't include the two nights hotel stay or breakfast and snacks and incidentals. But I can cover some of that myself, I just need help with the ticket. Plus I think I can get a room share, and there is a Tim Hortons across the street from the hotel where I can get breakfast on the cheap. 

If I don't make the whole $600 there are one day options or options without lunch and dinner that cost less. But what is the fun in only going to session after session and not getting all that socializing and networking at meal times! So I am crossing my fingers that you are all super generous!

What is so awesome about the Surrey International Writers Conference:

  • An intense line up of workshops and sessions with skilled and experienced authors such as Chuck Wendig, Diana Gabaldon, Anne Perry, Jack Whyte and more.
  • A big conference with a small intimate feel. You can literally bump into famous best-selling authors in the halls and they will just chat with you like regular folk.
  • Included in the cost of the ticket is a Blue Pencil session where one of the amazing authors reads your work and gives you tips!
  • As part of the whole package you get a 10 minute pitch session with an agent or editor! 
  • And the most valuable thing of all...a chance to rub elbows with other writers of all skill levels, and make lasting friendships.

What I get out of this:

  • I might learn how to write my way out of a wet paper bag, or an alien invasion....and then you all will get to hear the end of the story I started above.
  • I get to make interesting connections with actual live human beings...not just my characters. 
  • I may finally learn the mysteries of the semi-colon; or i may not. :P
  • I have this rockin' crow costume that I have been dying to wear, only I keep chickening out every time I get a chance to wear it. The friday night banquet is costumes optional. (If I actually make the full $600 I promise as a bonus to everyone that I will wear the costume no matter how self-conscious I feel.)
  • If I learn to write more better, you will enjoy my stories more better. (Most of you who donate are going to be my family and friends--the very same people who I will cajole into reading my stories, right? If you don't want to be in that awkward situation one day of saying, "Oh my god, this book is sooo awful, what am I gonna say if she asks me what I thought??" then you have a vested interest in helping me improve my writing!)

What you get out of this (The Perks):

  1. Basic: I finish the story, and you find out if Amanda escapes the alien robot invasion. 
  2. Cast a Character: Give me a name, and label ""good guy" or "bad guy" and I will write them into the story as a character of that orientation. This is a chance to see your name up in lights, honor a lost pet, get revenge on an annoying neighbor...whatever. 
  3. Write your way out of this one! Ha ha!: Give me a phrase, a situation, a writing prompt of some kind and I will figure out some way of working it into the story, and getting my character out of the spot she ends up in. Feel free to really challenge me. But let's make a rule: no vampires. Right? I mean, do I have to explain?
  4. Make me perform like a monkey: Yep, not only will I write the story but I will perform it on video and post it on YouTube. And just to make it worthwhile for more than just one person to purchase this option, for every person who does, I will make a new video of me reading/performing something else of mine--a song I wrote when I was 15, lame poetry, chapters from books I am writing, short stories, etc. I am sure I have enough material to humiliate myself multiple times. And I will dedicate each one to the person whose donation made it happen.
  5. One day, when I'm famous, you'll want this one: Your very own signed copy of the story printed on good quality multi-purpose paper, warm and fresh out of my printer on normal printing--not that fast draft crap--stapled together by one standard, stainless steel staple, and hand delivered to your mailbox by a member of the postal service (must be in US or Canada). Each will include it's own unique, hand-drawn, stick-figure, cover art page.
  6. Pick my brain: If you are a fellow writer and want to get in on some knowledge osmosis, then, after I get back from Surrey--and I am the master of all things writing--I will get on a Google Hangout with you and I will share everything...everything that I can remember...about the writing knowledge stuff...cuz, you know, what happens at the con, stays at the con. 
  7. Critique from the Master: Again, one for the writers out there. Once I am enlightened by the wise words of the Surrey International Writers Conference, if you have something you have written and want my feedback, I will give you a critique on up to 20 pages. (Double spaced, in 12pt Arial font, with standard margins...yadda yadda). Warning: this ain't your momma's feedback, I will be brutally honest, but I will also include explanations of where I think you went wrong and suggestions of how you might make improvements.

Goal hitting bonus: If I make the entire $600 I will make sure to take a picture of me dressed in my crow costume at the Surrey International Writers Conference. No matter how humiliating it might be.

Push Goals: If I make more than $600 I will be able to put that toward hotel room, travel, and other expenses--and I will be able to have an even better time at the conference. As a reward I will write extra chapters for the alien invasion story.

If I don't make all the money: I will still be going to the conference, I may have to sit on a the street corner outside the hotel with a coffee cup from Tim Hortons, or maybe bring my guitar and people can toss coins at me to stop playing (I'm not very good)--or I may just end up buying the cheaper ticket for a single day. But I will go, and I will use whatever donations I get to make that happen. 

You can give more than just money!

Maybe you don't have the money to contribute, or you just have a little and wish you could do more. Well you can! Here are some things you could do that would be like pure gold to me:

  • Share this campaign! Get the word out! Make some noise. The more people who see it the better!
  • Reads and reviews! I have a free short story out there called "Clean Slate" in ePub format; available just about anywhere you can buy an eBook. It's a "novelette" and it will take you maybe an hour or so to read--and its free. I would love to have your honest review! Even just 3 stars (I know it has some flaws).
  • I also have books on Wattpad (you can read without making an account, you only need one to comment and vote), a few scenes written on Google plus under the hashtag #byamandajunehagarty, fan me on Facebook, and check out my author website. I really appreciate reads and feeback!

Thank you!

Thanks for checking out my campaign and a big thank you if you contributed or went on to check out my writing. You are amazing!!
