And just to make it worthwhile for more than just one person to purchase this option, for every person who does, I will make a new video of me reading/performing something else of mine--a song I wrote when I was 15, lame poetry, chapters from books I am writing, short stories, etc. I am sure I have enough material to humiliate myself multiple times. And I will dedicate each one to the person whose donation made it happen.

One day, when I'm famous, you'll want this one: Your very own signed copy of the story printed on good quality multi-purpose paper, warm and fresh out of my printer on normal printing--not that fast draft crap--stapled together by one standard, stainless steel staple, and hand delivered to your mailbox by a member of the postal service (must be in US or Canada). Each will include it's own unique, hand-drawn, stick-figure, cover art page.

Pick my brain: If you are a fellow writer and want to get in on some knowledge osmosis, then, after I get back from Surrey--and I am the master of all things writing--I will get on a Google Hangout with you and I will share everything...everything that I can remember...about the writing knowledge stuff...cuz, you know, what happens at the con, stays at the con. 

Critique from the Master: Again, one for the writers out there. Once I am enlightened by the wise words of the Surrey International Writers Conference, if you have something you have written and want my feedback, I will give you a critique on up to 20 pages. (Double spaced, in 12pt Arial font, with standard margins...yadda yadda). Warning: this ain't your momma's feedback, I will be brutally honest, but I will also include explanations of where I think you went wrong and suggestions of how you might make improvements.
Goal hitting bonus: If I make the entire $600 I will make sure to take a picture of me dressed in my crow costume at the Surrey International Writers Conference. No matter how humiliating it might be.Push Goals: If I make more than $600 I will be able to put that toward hotel room, travel, and other expenses--and I will be able to have an even better time at the conference. As a reward I will write extra chapters for the alien invasion story.If I don't make all the money: I will still be going to the conference, I may have to sit on a the street corner outside the hotel with a coffee cup from Tim Hortons, or maybe bring my guitar and people can toss coins at me to stop playing (I'm not very good)--or I may just end up buying the cheaper ticket for a single day. But I will go, and I will use whatever donations I get to make that happen. You can give more than just money!Maybe you don't have the money to contribute, or you just have a little and wish you could do more. Well you can! Here are some things you could do that would be like pure gold to me:
Share this campaign! Get the word out! Make some noise. The more people who see it the better!
Reads and reviews! I have a free short story out there called "Clean Slate" in ePub format; available just about anywhere you can buy an eBook. It's a "novelette" and it will take you maybe an hour or so to read--and its free. I would love to have your honest review! Even just 3 stars (I know it has some flaws).
I also have books on Wattpad (you can read without making an account, you only need one to comment and vote), a few scenes written on Google plus under the hashtag #byamandajunehagarty, fan me on Facebook, and check out my author website. I really appreciate reads and feeback!
Thank you!Thanks for checking out my campaign and a big thank you if you contributed or went on to check out my writing. You are amazing!!

story:
Inspire youth to change the world through STEM!

Science and technology lie at the heart of the modern world, yet intensive STEM (science, tech, engineering and math) education is often regarded as too expensive, difficult or out of reach to bring to students in today’s under-resourced schools. ELiTE aims to change this notion by bringing cost-efficient, rigorous, and cutting-edge STEM programs to secondary school students across the world.

ELiTE is an education-focused nonprofit based in New York City. We are a young organization, composed of teachers, engineers, non-profit leaders, scientists, lawyers and entrepreneurs who came together five years ago to tackle the growing rift between science education and society, especially for students from lower income brackets. ELiTE seeks to empower low opportunity students from under-resourced backgrounds with engineering and science education to promote creative thinking and social responsibility. What began five years ago as a hands-on science summer camp in rural Ghana has since expanded to high school summer camps in Tanzania, Jamaica and Mexico, and year round student activities in Ghana and Harlem, NYC.

“The ability to create is the most empowering thing to happen to an individual” 
- Patrick Awuah, an ex-Microsoft techie and founder of Ashesi University, the top-ranked private liberal arts college in Ghana

Help ELiTE bring rigorous science education to more students!

In the past six months, ELiTE has expanded programs across Harlem and abroad, running credit-bearing classroom instruction in computer programming, robotics and environmental science for students in 6th through 12th grade during the academic day, after school clubs, and summer camps. This summer we are developing new curriculum to include a bioengineering course that empowers students to address issues in global health through scientific principles. In this new course, students will apply the engineering design process to create low-cost medical devices that can be used in developing communities.

The catch? With a full-time staff of one employee (and many dedicated volunteers!), ELiTE needs to deepen it’s pockets and hire new team-mates!

ELiTE was founded on the support of friends, family and the ‘crowd’. In the next year, ELiTE has plans to expand the reach of our programs, through new curricula in more classrooms. We are once again calling on the public to support our cause and broaden the reach of impactful science and technology education to students in need. Every dollar we raise on this campaign will directly impact one of the new students we reach with enabling hands-on science education.

The ELiTE Engine: A Recipe for Impact

  • Gears (Equipment) - Equipment and materials are necessary in order to keep our wheels turning. Funding to purchase equipment for new STEM curricula, including open source-electronics like Raspberry Pi computers, Arduino microcontroller, probes, and other cool stuff will allow us to engage students in new ways this year.

  • Fuel (Team) - Stipends for new hard-working facilitators who can guide students through our hands-on curricula and mentor them during their design projects. At ELiTE, we don’t call anyone ‘teachers’, because our students learn through discovery, exploration and team-work. Our facilitators lead and encourage our students, they don’t ‘instruct’ them!

  • Oxygen (Capacity) - ELiTE has accomplished so much without a full-time staff, but imagine what we could accomplish with a team devoted entirely to ELiTE. Help us raise funds to hire a new staff member!

Let’s match donations from Google!

Google has generously offered to match every dollar raised on Indiegogo up to $5,000. If we can reach $5000 in donations by June 27th, Google will give us another $5,000!


All students deserve access to STEM education!

A traditional lack of access to exceptional academics, typically reserved for their affluent counterparts, significantly limits boys and girls alike from pursuing STEM coursework at a secondary or post-secondary level. The driving force of ELiTE’s school based programs is to deliver rigorous, high quality STEM instruction and expose underrepresented students to lucrative technology driven careers. Our programs also seek to better prepare students for success in their STEM coursework in and beyond high school. ELiTE partners with public schools who may not have the capacity to facilitate after-school and enrichment programming of this nature.

Schools systems, such as the NYC Board of Education, the largest in the nation, have been slow to respond to the urgency of increasing access to quality STEM instruction, leaving behind 70% of the student body. And although the NYCDOE is comprised of approximately 32% African American and 39% Latino students, African Americans and Latino students make up only 7% and 9% of the population in NYC’s top 10 high schools. High-needs students continue to lack access, enrollment and participation in more rigorous science and mathematics courses, greatly reducing their chances of gaining admission to top universities.

Various factors have been identified that significantly influence the participation of racial and ethnic minority students in STEM at the K-12 level. Among them are early exposure to STEM fields; STEM opportunity and support programs; interest in STEM careers; and self-efficacy in STEM subjects. Self-efficacy emphasizes the role of observational and experiential learning in a social context embedded in the learning process.

ELiTE’s program model directly addresses these core factors in an effort to guide more minority students into STEM careers. Our ambitious efforts to expand access to high-quality STEM academic programs have reached over 200 middle school and high school students in the past two years, along with hundreds of high school students at our international summer programs in Ghana, Jamaica, Tanzania and Mexico. Rather than leaving at-risk and under-resourced youth behind, let’s recognize their true potential and give them the tools to drive change in the future!

Join the movement!

  • Tweet about ELiTE to your followers

  • Post and share this page on Facebook

  • Follow Emerging Leaders in Technology and Engineering on Facebook, G+, Twitter, and Linkedin

  • Email your friends and family

  • Run through the streets shouting at the top of your breath "I am ELiTE"!

  • Donate $75 or more and receive your limited edition "i am elite" t-shirt

  • Ask your employer about matching donation programs. Email development@elite-education.org for more information on how to do this.


Awards and Recognition

Recipient of the prestigious Google RISE award in 2012, to introduce rigorous hands-on STEM education in Harlem, NYC

Selection as a Google RISE Partnership grant awardee in 2013 (with WAAW Foundation) to bring computer science education to over 5,000 girls across seven countries in Africa

Winner of the Ashoka, My City, Our Voice competition, with an award to sponsor our school-year coding, robotics and environmental science programs in New York City.

Support from the West Harlem Development Corporation, for our work with under-served youth from the West Harlem neighborhood in New York City.

Selection of ELiTE’s President, Chelsey Roebuck, as an Echoing Green Black Male Achievement Fellow.

Press Coverage

Real Money with Ali Velshihttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J47JbnxojNo

TEDx Columbia Engineering http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tpkb12DitZ8

Make Homepage/Blog http://makezine.com/2013/09/12/engineering-and-science-education-for-everyone

My Voice, Our City (City of NY Announcement) http://www1.nyc.gov/office-of-the-mayor/news/325-13/mayor-bloomberg-ashoka-changemakers-winners-young-men-s-initiative-competition

Diverse Issues in Higher Education http://mydigimag.rrd.com/print.php?pages=8&issue_id=168309&ref=1

Empower Magazine http://www.empowermagazine.com/echoing-green-fellows-take-on-black-male-achievement/

Columbia Spectator  http://www.columbiaspectator.com/news/2013/11/12/nonprofit-founded-alum-expands-local-stem-programs

Inside Philanthropy (Re: MLT)  http://philanthropyjournal.blogspot.com/2013/12/creating-personal-roadmap-to-leadership.html

Want to learn more?

ELiTE welcomes support of any kind, ranging from monetary gifts to donations in kind, volunteer support as a facilitator or a dedicated fan, service support such as photography, website development or pro bono legal assistance, and beyond. If you want to get involved in any capacity beyond this Indiegogo campaign, please email Chelsey@elite-education.org.

The Team

Chelsey Roebuck, Founder and President

Clayton Dahlman, Founder and Vice-President

Jean Tickell, Development

Kevin Smith, R&D Engineer

Sam Bhattacharyya, R&D Engineer

Ritish Patnaik, Curriculum Development

Paramita Roy, Education Intern

Jesse Matza, R&D Intern

Morgan Caglianone, R&D Intern

story:
Summary:

I coordinate medical care for law enforcement officers doing ongoing training and for candidates in their initial police academy training. These men and women push themselves to excel, much like professional athletes would, to learn and demonstrate physically demanding defensive tactic maneuvers so they are able to successfully overpower resistance from persons they arrest who chose to fight with them.

A result of the intensity of and physical contact with others this training requires, often results in muscle soreness and occasionally in injuries, despite taking reasonable precautions for safety. As a core component of the “R-I-C-E” (rest-ice-compression-elevation) method, we need large amounts of ice for cold compresses and cold immersion treatment to reduce pain and swelling of the sore or injured areas. We have lost our source for ice and need your help to fund a new, high-capacity, ice machine to make the ice that will help our law enforcement athletes quickly return to training and work.

Need:

To be able to care for these sore trainees will require a commercial ice maker with storage unit, which will cost approximately $2600. The connection and filters for the unit will cost approximately $400, and this will allow the ice made to be used in water coolers as well as for cold therapy.

Impact:

Your donation and the success of this fundraiser will help me to support these academy candidates and in-service law enforcement personnel to remain in their training through completion, instead of risking medical disqualification due to injuries that could have been treated on-site. You will be helping dedicated young men and women​​ from multiple jurisdictions complete their academy training to become sworn officers to protect the public. All funds raised will go towards direct patient support needs (this ice machine) and patient care.

Challenges:

Regulations prohibit direct acceptance of gifts, however through this community fundraiser, you have the opportunity to support your law enforcement and contribute to the training and successful graduation of new officers who provide us protection. Please consider donating and spreading the word so we can achieve our goal! Thank you for your support!

story:
Background:

Religious extremism is the main hurdle in the way of education especially female education in Afghanistan. Schools  are burnt and students and teachers are killed by extremist and terrorists. In order to deter the religious extremism and evil of ignorance it is needed that schools should be established and young generation shall get education. 

Introduction: 

I am Musarat Hussain a women education rights advocate as I believe that "an educated female means an educated generation". In order to deter the extremism, terrorism, poverty and child labor in rug weaving business, I registered the Refah School with Ministry of Education Afghanistan in the year 2006. Non-for-profit, co-education, computer classes, English literacy and qualified female teachers are the unique features of the school which is not existing in Afghanistan.  There are more than 250 pupils enrolled in class 1 to 9 where 40% of the students and and 80% the teachers are female. A Board of Directors (BoD) comprising of three other committed members Ali Hemat, Mustafa Ahmadi and Nasratullah Omed are responsible for the overall affairs of the school. 

   

   

Rug weaving another curse for Afghan girls: 

Rug weaving is a traditional skill of Afghans but during the Afghan war 1990-2001 the home based industry became the main source of income of Afghan refugees, IDPs and returnees. The nature of the work finally found children especially female ones, a cheap and obedient human resource who used to weave rug for 6 to 12 hours on daily basis in a 6x6 feet wooden frame. This way the parents themselves became economically depending on their children. They were not in a position to let their children go school but they expected them to weave rug and earn livelihood for the whole family. One of the parents said "if you want our children to attend school  then you have to pay for their daily wages otherwise we will be left hungry". 

Campaign and it's importance: 

Refah School is a ray of hope for the rug weaving communities and also a sense of peace and stability for the people who are living in the insecure poor district 13 of Kabul, Afghanistan. We believe that "all the human beings have the basic right to get education and also basic responsibility to protect education". 

  


School finances since inception: 

Since 2006 Refah School could have generate an overall business loop of more than 100,000 US$ in the locality in form of fees, salaries, renting building and miscellaneous expenses like uniform/dress, stationary, tools, refreshment etc. The percentage of overall business generated is comprised of 26% fees, 35% salaries, 15% rented school building and 24% miscellaneous expenses.  

So fare the direct investment in the school involves more than 45,000 US$. The founder of the school has contributed 77% of the investment amount whereas the rest of the 23% investment has been contributed by BoD and certain independent contributions.

Estimated budget for 2015: 

The total budget for  the educational year 2015 is estimated around 20,000 US$ for the 250 pupils (6.6 US$ per student/per month).  The income from fees is estimated 15,000 US$ (5 US$ per student/per month) whereas 5,000 US$ will be the deficit and it should be contributed by the founder, BoD and certain independent contributors. In order to start the educational year 2015 on 21st of March we will be in need of 1,000 US$ which will make the total amount 6,000 US$ and the present the campaign through Indiegogo is for the same amount. 

Reaching the entire goal:

Refah School has been established gradually and by now all the staff members are trained enough. The behavior of the students are also important aspect that the staff members need to polish and control. On the other hand dealing with parents and community members also need a great effort. Once all these done then one can say that the school has been established and sustained. There are formalities and procedures to follow both within the institution and also during reporting process with the relevant governmental authorities. Founding and establishing an institution is a great challenge that is what the eight years of the school has practically taught us and we will keep it up. 

The Impact: 

Female education in Afghanistan is not warranted by certain religious and traditional people. Refah School has the pride of educating female in co-education system in Afghanistan where females are not allowed even to attend segregated schools. Moreover female teachers have been employed who are restricted from jobs and appearing in public. 

Value to the contributor and to the world:

Education is basic to a peaceful and prosperous life and society. It is the responsibility of all to take part in educating others especially when participation is possible by contributing a small amount of money otherwise it is a life long struggle. In countries like Afghanistan which has been destroyed because of international politics and interference, by now we are fortunate enough to play a positive role in bringing tranquility once again. 

Successful track record:

It is the 8th successful year of Refah School serving the communities. During this period of time the capacities of the staff have been built in management and teaching. The reporting and communications with the Ministry of Education also have been properly established. 

A reality and a trust:

Refah School has proved itself as a standard and capable institution educating the young pupils. The whole community has confidence in the school and they appreciate its role in over all development of the area. The Ministry of Education always gets the periodic reports on time and its officials has recorded their satisfaction during their periodic visits to the school. 

Risks & Challenges: 

Afghanistan is one of the most dangerous places on earth where ongoing insurgency is causing casualties on daily basis. Our children and teachers is under threat of being killed and school are bombed. We are already taking the risks for educating our new generation and making the world safer for us and also for our fellow beings. So far we have been successful and faced all the challenges and we expect that we will definitely win against all the odds.  

Other Ways You Can Help: 

The Refah School as an institution has a comprehensive role in the lives of its pupils. We are in need of in-kind contributions as well. You can help us by donating your old computers, lap tops, printers, laboratory equipment, stationary and sports tools.

Contact: 

Musarat Hussain,

email: musarat.hussain@gmail.com

In order to start the educational year 2015 on 21st of March we will be in need of 1,000 US$ which will make the total amount 6,000 US$ and the present the campaign through Indiegogo is for the same amount. Reaching the entire goal:Refah School has been established gradually and by now all the staff members are trained enough. The behavior of the students are also important aspect that the staff members need to polish and control. On the other hand dealing with parents and community members also need a great effort. Once all these done then one can say that the school has been established and sustained. There are formalities and procedures to follow both within the institution and also during reporting process with the relevant governmental authorities. Founding and establishing an institution is a great challenge that is what the eight years of the school has practically taught us and we will keep it up. The Impact: Female education in Afghanistan is not warranted by certain religious and traditional people. Refah School has the pride of educating female in co-education system in Afghanistan where females are not allowed even to attend segregated schools. Moreover female teachers have been employed who are restricted from jobs and appearing in public. Value to the contributor and to the world:Education is basic to a peaceful and prosperous life and society. It is the responsibility of all to take part in educating others especially when participation is possible by contributing a small amount of money otherwise it is a life long struggle. In countries like Afghanistan which has been destroyed because of international politics and interference, by now we are fortunate enough to play a positive role in bringing tranquility once again. Successful track record:It is the 8th successful year of Refah School serving the communities. During this period of time the capacities of the staff have been built in management and teaching. The reporting and communications with the Ministry of Education also have been properly established. A reality and a trust:Refah School has proved itself as a standard and capable institution educating the young pupils. The whole community has confidence in the school and they appreciate its role in over all development of the area. The Ministry of Education always gets the periodic reports on time and its officials has recorded their satisfaction during their periodic visits to the school. Risks & Challenges: Afghanistan is one of the most dangerous places on earth where ongoing insurgency is causing casualties on daily basis. Our children and teachers is under threat of being killed and school are bombed. We are already taking the risks for educating our new generation and making the world safer for us and also for our fellow beings. So far we have been successful and faced all the challenges and we expect that we will definitely win against all the odds.  Other Ways You Can Help: The Refah School as an institution has a comprehensive role in the lives of its pupils. We are in need of in-kind contributions as well. You can help us by donating your old computers, lap tops, printers, laboratory equipment, stationary and sports tools.Contact: Musarat Hussain,email: musarat.hussain@gmail.com

story:
What Is Magistrula.com?

Salve! I'm Anna Andresian. I became a Latin teacher in the year 2000, and two years later, Magistrula.com was born when a preschooler found an action figure that looked like me in the classroom box of toys at the Rocky Hill School in RI. She became a kind of mascot for my middle and upper school Latin classes, and Magistrula.com documented her adventures with a silly collection of pictures and songs.

In 2012, when I was teaching at the Lawrenceville School in NJ, I attended a programming club taught by two senior boys (Jonathan Tang & Oliver Barnum). I became addicted to programming and started turning Magistrula.com into a Latin learning website with exercises and games to help my students practice Latin grammar. 

Students can practice charts, forms, translation, and composition using exercises that can be customized to fit particular learning goals for a topic. Users can also design zombie games to help with memorizing vocabulary, key terms, mythology, etc. Teachers can create assignments and then view student work after it has been completed.

This site changed the way I was able to differentiate instruction in class and the way students were able to practice the material independently outside of class. A new-and-improved version of Magistrula.com was launched in January 2014, and the site now has several hundred active users and is growing every day! In 2014, I transitioned from my career as a teacher to a career as a software engineer, and it's exciting to apply the things I learn at work to my continued development of Magistrula.com.

Fundraising Needs

I need to raise $2000 in 2015 to cover the cost of production-level web hosting, database storage, and security as well subscription fees for various products that I use to develop the site. I funded the site on my own in 2014, but, unfortunately, that is not a sustainable model. I don't want to clutter the site with ads, nor do I want to require a signup fee; I want the site to be completely open to anyone who wants to use it! I am hoping to fund the site each year through donations. Please help me establish long-term stability for Magistrula.com and keep it free for all users!

story:
MY DESPERATE PLEA FOR MONEY

Hi everybody!

Im sure all you guys have heard that I'm writing my thesis on Taxi Drivers in Singapore. If you haven't, find me so i can bore you with my story and my grand ideas! But basically, my research involves me riding taxis and talking to the very same uncles that bring you around everyday and finding out about their life stories!

However, my pursuit of academia has severely wrecked my personal fund (as you all you know, im poor as a dog!) and this is my personal (kinda lame) attempt to get more from you guys!

Currently i need about 12 more interviews of 20mins to get this thing through this period of time. So you do the math, its gonna take up alot of money from me.

If you were lazy to do that math, its about 12 dollars a ride, which means 12 X 12 = $$144. 

If you guys can help me get to that number, or even anywhere close to it! I WILL BE SO VERY VERY VERY GRATEFUL!

MY CONFESSION

Honestly, my thesis is not gonna change or revolutionise anything. In fact, nobody is probably gonna read it. But i need to graduate! 

How you can help? Donate to my thesis fund. Any amount will do, seriously :) And when I get my A, I will forever be indebted to your kind deeds and will do anything you want me to do. Yes anything!

Other Ways You Can Help

Well honestly, money isn't everything here. Theres Uber. Those of you who still do not have Uber, GO DOWNLOAD IT, its awesome, its cool and it gives me a $10 discount if you sign up for it and enter clarencet34 in your promo code. If you parents dont have it, help me download for them and add this. 

Dont worry, the sharing goes both ways and you too get a $10 discount on your first ride! Everybody's happy :)

story:
Child Sexual Abuse is an ICKY SUBJECT.
But We Need To Start The Conversation.


Join "Team Simon!"

Be part of a movement of caring adults all over the globe who believe that every child deserves a safe and peaceful childhood.

And that the epidemic of child sexual abuse
must end.


Please help us raise $5000.00 toward needed program materials.

And help make Simon become an international symbol of children's rights and the prevention of child sexual abuse. 


You can get cool perks and be part of one of the most important movements happening in the world today.


About #TheIcky:

  • ‘The Icky’ is an Epidemic That Affects 1 in 4 Girls and 1 in 7 Boys Before the Age of 18. (U.S. Dept. of Justice, National Sex Offender Public Website, 2014)
  •  Collective silence causes grave damage to millions of children – and  protects the abusers. 

  • It is the 2nd Most Expensive Victim Crime Behind Murder, Costing the U.S.$35 Billion annually. (Center for Economic Policy and Research, 2010)
  • Children of Every Gender, Age, Race, Ethnicity, Background, Socioeconomic Status and Family Structure Are at Risk.  No Child is Immune.
  • It is Pandemic – Affecting Millions of Children Around the Globe.
*************************************************************************


How We #StoptheIcky:

Stop Abuse ~ Powered By Spectrum Puppets
produces an Emmy award-winning musical marionette program called "Simon Says Just Tell"

 “Simon Says, ‘Just Tell’” has been performed to more than 250,000 children in greater HamptonRoads, Virginia and throughout the US and Canada. It’s proven effective in teaching children how to recognize, prevent and disclose abuse. Children learn self-worth, empowerment and that ‘their body is their own’ in a non-threatening, entertaining way. Thousands of cases of abuse have been prevented and 158 child abusers are behind bars as a direct result of the program, in Hampton Roads, VA alone.

*****************************************

Join A Global Campaign For Education + Awareness
Empowerment + Love

Part 1:  Donations Needed

Our In-Service Training Video Needs Updating

Stop abuse is working to update its 4 part child sexual abuse prevention program - the most comprehensive and effective evidence-based program of its kind.

Funding is needed to update the In-Service Training Video, which will include the participation of top national experts in child abuse prevention, law enforcement and education.

Desired Goal:  $5000.00


Part 2:  "SELFIES WITH SIMON"

Please Help Simon Become An International Symbol of Children's Rights.

The first 1,000 ($25.00) donors will receive an adorable Simon Doll. Send us your "Selfie with Simon."  We'll post it to our Facebook and Twitter pages with a Huge Personalized Thanks to You!   You can post the photos to your social media with #StopAbuse Simon and #StoptheIcky hashtags.

Send photos to info@stopabuse.com

*****************************************

"If We Are To Have Real Peace In This World We Shall Have To Begin With The Children." – Mohandas K. Ghandi

story:
When my son was 21 he experienced a psychotic break as a result of mania in bipolar disorder.  This is when a person's mind loses touch with reality. He was in university at the time. He was treated at LHSC in London, Ontario and participated in the PEPP program (Program for Prevention and Early Intervention for Psychoses). The social part of the program was especially helpful for him both as an in patient and later as an outpatient for two months.  One program,
RAP (Recovery, Activity and Participation) was especially crucial to his recovery, and he started to paint as therapy which he continues to do 14 years later. I have included a recent watercolour of his.

 


I would like to raise money for food, video rentals and art supplies that are currently non funded by the hospital in the social and therapeutic program at PEPP. 

 


The impact is to raise awareness of psychosis in young people and in mental illness in general. There is a lot of stigma attached to mental illness but people can learn more about it from agencies such as the Canadian Association for Mental Health. 


   


 People can also look at Touched by Fire's web site an art show for artists with mental illness (www.touchedbyfire.co) This show is sponsored by the Mood Disorders Association of Ontario

story:
What We Do 

SCHOOL Kids Yoga Classes integrate yoga and meditation techniques, mindful movement, calm breathing, and themed stories to teach children how to self-initiate a calm body, brain, and most importantly, a calm heart.

We teach weekly, 20-minute classes for Pre-K through 5th grade students throughout the school year, because consistency is key to fostering positive social, emotional, and academic skills.

"My students have been able to focus more, listen more attentively, show respect for each other's feelings, and think before acting. I find myself stopping to breathe and calm my mind before reacting to stressful situations, especially in my classroom. I am so grateful to have been given the opportunity to be a part of this new learning for my students and for myself.” –Liz, 4th Grade Teacher 


We know the importance of giving children tools to self-regulate their emotions in the early years of life. SCHOOL nurtures social/emotional learning in our students at a crucial stage in their development. We teach self-confidence and the importance of caring for others -- so that today's children grow into adults who contribute to healthy communities. 

What sets us apart is our holistic approach, which addresses the needs of students, teachers, and the classroom as a whole. In addition to SCHOOL classes, we offer Teacher Trainings for public school teachers, who are eager to learn practical methods for managing the classroom and reducing stress.


Our Background

Kelly Wood (E-RYT 200, RCYT, RPYT) created the 501(c)(3) nonprofit SCHOOL, Inc. in 2012, drawing from more than 12 years experience teaching over 220,000 elementary school children. 

Kelly developed SCHOOL Kids Yoga Classes to help children and teachers in underserved public schools adapt constructively to growing stress and distraction, in school and in life. 



Our Goal

After a successful crowdfunding campaign last year, we were able to provide SCHOOL Kids Yoga Classes for 1,000 children and 50 public school teachers each week of the 2013-2014 school year. This year, more teachers and schools are requesting our classes. 

Your support will help us meet the growing demand for our programs in LA County schools for the 2014-2015 academic year. 

We are raising $5,000 to cover:

* Program expenses for SCHOOL classes

* Teacher fees ($20/class for lead teacher and those trained by Kelly)

* Training scholarships for public school teachers ($250 per teacher) 




DONATE NOW and join our mission to create positive, healthy learning environments!

With your generous donation, we will again reach over 1,000 children in LA Unified and Pasadena Unified School Districts in 2014-2015. Your support will also provide 20 scholarships for public school teachers to attend SCHOOL Teacher Trainings. 


Why Donate to SCHOOL? 

Research shows that mindfulness-based approaches in education promote children’s emotional health, attention and cognition, social adaptation, and academic success. 

Today, children are increasingly affected by ADD/ADHD, autism, and chronic childhood stress -- which is common in high-poverty neighborhoods. SCHOOL is committed to addressing these issues in our public schools and supporting healthy social/emotional development in our children. 

Public schools have limited funding. By coming together as a caring community, we can improve our schools and thus, invest in our future. 



    Other Ways You Can Help

    Help us get the word out, and make some noise about our SCHOOL campaign!

    1. Use the Indiegogo share tools at the top of the page to share with friends via email or social media. 

    2. Cut and paste the following onto your Facebook or Twitter pages: 

    Sample Facebook post: 

    Help bring yoga and meditation to elementary school kids in LA public schools, and get online yoga classes! Join me in donating to SCHOOL’s fundraiser on Indiegogo: http://bit.ly/schoolinc

    Sample Twitter post: 

    Support yoga & meditation in LA elementary schools & get online yoga classes from @kellywoodyoga! Donate to SCHOOL’s Indiegogo fundraiser: http://bit.ly/schoolinc


    THANK YOU!

story:
I have a student in Cambodia who I've been in touch with for the last few years. He currently works 20 hours per day and only makes the equivalent of $60 US per month, which is very little even considering how cheap the living costs are there. He asked me to help him with some money so he can return to school and provide for his family and village, as they can only afford rice and have very little to be sustained.

While I was teaching English there, he offered to help me be an interpreter for other students since his English was the best in class, and I have a special place for him in my heart. He's a wonderful person and it's hard for me to hear that he is struggling like this. I'm wondering if you'd be willing to help me by donating a few dollars so I can raise money for him to return to school so he can get a better job. Anything would help- There's no pressure at all, but it for a good cause.  Good Karma!  Always remember to pay it forward :)

story:
What We're About...

Youth on the Move (YOTM) is an after-school enrichment program for vulnerable middle school youth. These students are underserved and under-supported youth from low-income households.  Priority registration is given to students referred by counselors and teachers at Davidson Middle School in San Rafael, CA, where 60% of students qualify for free/reduced lunch (parents living at poverty level). Access to quality afterschool and summer activities for middle school youth is the number one concern of their parents, who often work two jobs to support their family in this otherwise affluent area of Marin County, California.

A unique component of this program is service-learning opportunities that teach youth life-skills as well as giving them the opportunity to make a real difference in their community. Service trips impact the students’ sense of belonging to a community in positive ways as they interact with intergenerational mentors.

Youth on the Move provides a “safe place” for youth after school while promoting the many benefits of altruism, including increased self-assurance, empathy, mental and physical health, social and leadership skills. 

YOTM is a non-sectarian program with no religious instruction. We are a 501 (3) (C) non-profit organization and 100% of your donation is tax-deductable.

Help us raise $5,000 by August 23 to provide much-needed scholarships for this  program!

 

Why we need this funding...  KEEPING LIVES ON TRACK

Students moving into adolescence face myriad challenges and opportunities, both in school and after school.  These students are too old for after-school child care programs, and opportunities for positive social, recreational, and developmental experiences are non-existent, not convenient, or too expensive for many Davidson students’ parents.  Many students need special help with school work as they undertake more challenging math, English and social studies classes.  Failure to successfully complete the middle school work and achieve positive transition to high school can lead to higher drop-out rates and the temptation to become involved in high-risk activities and groups.  

YOTM is offered Monday through Thursday from the end of school to 6 p.m., concurrent with both summer school and the regular school year.   At least two YMCA Counselors supervise daily activities, and volunteers assist with homework, snacks and field trips.  The program offers students: 

  • support for academic progress 
  • group community service with education and reflection components
  • a wide variety of enrichment activities such as trips to museums
  • wellness opportunities including sports, healthy cooking and snacks  

Special experiences during the 2012-13 school year included a trip to the NASA Museum in Novato, swimming lessons at the YMCA, healthy cooking classes with Kids Cooking for Life, instruction in bike riding and care from “Trips for Kids,” visits to the Museum for the American Indian, the Marin Humane Society , “Wild Care,” and much more!

 

Who We Are

First Presbyterian Church, with 250 members, is centrally located in downtown San Rafael in MarinCounty.  Our Board is comprised of 15 leaders with various business, education, and non-profit management backgrounds.  For generations, FPCSR has been active in social justice issues; we are involved in the affordable housing movement in Marin, regularly serve meals to hungry and homeless people, and are founding participants in the REST Winter Shelter Program.

FPCSR members have funded this program for an entire year.

This project is sponsored by our Social Justice Committee, chaired by Board Member Leslie Purdy, a retired community college president; other leaders on the Committee and for this project include Nancy and Ed Boyce, founders of MarinLink, and Lorna Wuertz, retired assistant principal of the middle school that we will serve.  Assoc. Pastor Jan Reynolds, with a background in business and non-profit management directs the project.  Members of our church and other congregations, local students and non-profits leaders volunteer.

Our Partners

We have partnered with stellar non-profit organizations to make this successful program run:

  • The Marin YMCA provides experienced counselors and the opportunity for swimming and sports at their San Rafael facility.
  • The Marin Food Bank provides low-cost, enriching food for snacks.
  • Kids Cooking for Life provide lessons on cooking delicious and healthy meals.
  • Trips for Kids provides bikes and lessons for safe biking and bike repair.
  • San Francisco Foundation has provided a grant and encouragement. 

 

What We Need

Our congregation has funded this program through individual donations, but wider community support is now needed for this program to continue long-term. A contribution of $2,500 provides support for one middle school student to participate in the YOTM program for one full year.  Contributions of any size will help create a Scholarship Fund to ensure student participation. 

All contributions are tax-deductible and will directly support this important program.  

 

Ways You Can Help:

Your donation will provide students a chance to improve academic success and social skills, and increased understanding of their self-worth that will support them in all aspects of life.

Provide a gift of any amount of your choice!  100% of every donation goes towards helping our youth benefit from the Youth on the Move program! We are a 501 (3)(C) non-profit organization and 100% of your donation is tax-deductable.

 

Spark a chain reaction of giving by sharing this campaign with family, friends, Facebook, and Twitter.  We need your help to spread the word!
story_txt:
What We're About...
Youth on the Move (YOTM) is an after-school enrichment program for vulnerable middle school youth. These students are underserved and under-supported youth from low-income households.  Priority registration is given to students referred by counselors and teachers at Davidson Middle School in San Rafael, CA, where 60% of students qualify for free/reduced lunch (parents living at poverty level). Access to quality afterschool and summer activities for middle school youth is the number one concern of their parents, who often work two jobs to support their family in this otherwise affluent area of Marin County, California.
A unique component of this program is service-learning opportunities that teach youth life-skills as well as giving them the opportunity to make a real difference in their community. Service trips impact the students’ sense of belonging to a community in positive ways as they interact with intergenerational mentors.
Youth on the Move provides a “safe place” for youth after school while promoting the many benefits of altruism, including increased self-assurance, empathy, mental and physical health, social and leadership skills. 
YOTM is a non-sectarian program with no religious instruction. We are a 501 (3) (C) non-profit organization and 100% of your donation is tax-deductable.
Help us raise $5,000 by August 23 to provide much-needed scholarships for this  program!
 
Why we need this funding...  KEEPING LIVES ON TRACK
Students moving into adolescence face myriad challenges and opportunities, both in school and after school.  These students are too old for after-school child care programs, and opportunities for positive social, recreational, and developmental experiences are non-existent, not convenient, or too expensive for many Davidson students’ parents.  Many students need special help with school work as they undertake more challenging math, English and social studies classes.  Failure to successfully complete the middle school work and achieve positive transition to high school can lead to higher drop-out rates and the temptation to become involved in high-risk activities and groups.  
YOTM is offered Monday through Thursday from the end of school to 6 p.m., concurrent with both summer school and the regular school year.   At least two YMCA Counselors supervise daily activities, and volunteers assist with homework, snacks and field trips.  The program offers students: 


support for academic progress 

group community service with education and reflection components

a wide variety of enrichment activities such as trips to museums

wellness opportunities including sports, healthy cooking and snacks  

Special experiences during the 2012-13 school year included a trip to the NASA Museum in Novato, swimming lessons at the YMCA, healthy cooking classes with Kids Cooking for Life, instruction in bike riding and care from “Trips for Kids,” visits to the Museum for the American Indian, the Marin Humane Society , “Wild Care,” and much more!
 
Who We Are
First Presbyterian Church, with 250 members, is centrally located in downtown San Rafael in MarinCounty.  Our Board is comprised of 15 leaders with various business, education, and non-profit management backgrounds.  For generations, FPCSR has been active in social justice issues; we are involved in the affordable housing movement in Marin, regularly serve meals to hungry and homeless people, and are founding participants in the REST Winter Shelter Program.
FPCSR members have funded this program for an entire year.
This project is sponsored by our Social Justice Committee, chaired by Board Member Leslie Purdy, a retired community college president; other leaders on the Committee and for this project include Nancy and Ed Boyce, founders of MarinLink, and Lorna Wuertz, retired assistant principal of the middle school that we will serve.  Assoc. Pastor Jan Reynolds, with a background in business and non-profit management directs the project.  Members of our church and other congregations, local students and non-profits leaders volunteer.
Our Partners
We have partnered with stellar non-profit organizations to make this successful program run:

The Marin YMCA provides experienced counselors and the opportunity for swimming and sports at their San Rafael facility.
The Marin Food Bank provides low-cost, enriching food for snacks.
Kids Cooking for Life provide lessons on cooking delicious and healthy meals.
Trips for Kids provides bikes and lessons for safe biking and bike repair.
San Francisco Foundation has provided a grant and encouragement. 


 
What We Need
Our congregation has funded this program through individual donations, but wider community support is now needed for this program to continue long-term. A contribution of $2,500 provides support for one middle school student to participate in the YOTM program for one full year.  Contributions of any size will help create a Scholarship Fund to ensure student participation. 
All contributions are tax-deductible and will directly support this important program.  
 
Ways You Can Help:
Your donation will provide students a chance to improve academic success and social skills, and increased understanding of their self-worth that will support them in all aspects of life.
Provide a gift of any amount of your choice!  100% of every donation goes towards helping our youth benefit from the Youth on the Move program! We are a 501 (3)(C) non-profit organization and 100% of your donation is tax-deductable.
 
Spark a chain reaction of giving by sharing this campaign with family, friends, Facebook, and Twitter.  We need your help to spread the word!

story:
Lake County High School and West Park Elementary schools were built in the early 1960's.  West Park has heating system pipes that were encapsulated within concrete during the construction process. Both buildings have pipes that do not have any zones or shut-off valves. Any leak that springs has a catastrophic effect for the entire system until repairs can be made.  The heating system piping is currently in a corroded condition that is typical for piping of this age. This portion of the infrastructure is a serious issue with the buildings.

 
The Lake County School District Facilities Plan identified many other deficiencies with our school buildings and the needs of the District. The plan was developed over two years by a joint facilities committee of community members and school district employees. The meetings were open and publicized for the maximum community involvement.

We were fortunate to get through this year; however, we felt it necessary to use some of the district budget to move forward. 

What does this mean? We are using district funds to match a grant application and at the same time begin the most critical work at West Park.  If we get the grant, we will replace some of the money into our 2012-2013 budget for necessary expenses.

What will the project involve? We will fix the heating and water pipes at West Park this summer and replace most of the unit ventilators in classrooms.

When will this portion of the repairs be complete? Prior to the start of the 2012-2013 school year.

What do we lose when we spend these dollars? We lose text materials, classroom equipment and supplies and the ability to do any other high cost repairs that may be needed during the school year.

Does this mean that we do not need any other funding for West Park or the district? No.  This is an emergency and must be done; but we are not fixing all the systems that need to be repaired at West Park including installing a sprinkler system, fixing the electrical wiring and upgrading technological capabilities in that building.

What about the high school? We have applied for a grant and must either go to the voters to match the grant or go to the voters to pay for the urgent repairs at the high school.  The systems are fragile; hopefully they will continue to function!

Please keep in mind that Lake County High School and West Park Elementary School were both built in the 1960’s.  As a result, many parts of the buildings have exceeded their useful life and are in need of critical repairs / replacements.

Over the past 10 years, the Lake County School District has received over $4 million dollars in grants that have been matched with local funds to repair immediate needs as prioritized by the Facilities Committee. Pitts Elementary and the Middle School have had extensive renovations.  West Park Elementary and the High School have major infrastructure issues, but the buildings are structurally sound.

This fundraising effort will secure money for the Citizens for Lake County Schools to campaign to pass a bond in November. Our schools must be fixed, and the district does not have the funding necessary to repair them.

 

Strong Schools = Strong Community

 

Please consider supporting our efforts. Thank you.

story:
Commitment to Teaching and Learning

My name is Maddie and I am a first year teacher of students with social and emotional disabilities.  My students are in 3rd and 4th grade and need some extra TLC to be successful in public school.  This campaign is to help reach my goal of furnishing a calming environment for my students to feel safe and ready to learn.  Prior to this year, I have been a paraprofessional for children with severe special needs, a graduate student, and a fulltime AmeriCorps volunteer in Boston, MA.

What I Need

My goal is posted as $500, but as many know, the cost to build a classroom can be thousands.  Your donation will directly impact students by providing materials for:

  • Library books
  • Furniture (beanbag chairs, pillows)
  • Math materials (blocks, rods, dice, pattern blocks)
  • Science materials (science notebooks, science station manipulatives)
  • Wall decorations (visuals, word wall, pocket charts, schedule)
  • Assistive Technologies (chair cushions, timers, fidget tools)

The Impact

Nothing is more rewarding than helping those in need.  Your contribution to this campaign not only helps moniterily, but it also connects you to a network of individuals who care about children, special needs, and education. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share my page and remember, every little bit helps!

story:
Who are we?

The Dance 411 Foundation is an Atlanta-based nonprofit which exposes inner-city youth to quality arts education and performances. Originally founded in 2004 as the Journey Arts Program, Director Samara Michelle wanted to ensure all children have access to the transformative dance education she received at a local nonprofit dance school in Detroit as a child, regardless of their socio-economic standing.

In January 2012, Journey Arts partnered with Dance411 Studio owners Sindy and Ed Schneider to form the Dance 411 Foundation. With strong roots in the East Atlanta community, Dance 411 provided the perfect base to support a mission of fostering the well-being of urban youth and adults through self-expression by providing quality education and exposure to the art and discipline of dance, drama, & music.

What is our project?

We are funding a new project: BRING ARTS BACK to School. This Campaign will provide Atlanta-area schools and community programs with both school supplies and arts education throughout the 2012-2013 academic school year. In order to pay the working artists and performers, the Dance 411 Foundation is raising $7500, which will cover our Artist Salaries. The planned recipients are Parkside Elementary ,The Kindezi School ,Dobbs Elementary, Dunbar Elementary ,Peyton Forest Elementary, CityCamp Program. More than 2500 children will be impacted by this initiative.

Campaign Details

July 1-Aug 31

Each Adopted School/Program will receive:

 

  • In-school Theatre performance of Chrysalis: Breakthrough – A Story of Surviving Bullying and Self Doubt

 

  • In-school Dance Performance from a well-known dance crew or professional Dance Performance Company

 

  • Two Arts Education Workshops – Music Dance or Acting Workshop

 

  • School Supplies for underserved students

 

How Can I Help?

 

For those who give $25 of support, you will received a special shoutout on Facebook and Twitter

 

For those who give $50 of support, you will receive a special shoutout on Facebook and Twitter PLUS a signed poster from the Chrysalis:Breakthrough

 

For those who give $100 of support, you will receive a special shoutout on Facebook and Twitter, a signed poster from the Chrysalis:Breakthrough PLUS special recognition on our website for the entire production season

 

Why is this a big deal?

School budget cuts are at an all time high. A 2008, national survey follow-up analysis by the Center on Education Policy showed, in the five years after enactment of No Child Left Behind, that 16 percent of school districts had reduced elementary school class time for music and art. Artistic programs like dance, drama and music were labeled “Non-essentials” and were the first to go. But according to recent studies highlighting the benefits of arts education; formal arts instruction for children result in the following:

Pro-social behavior

Enhanced academic achievement

Improved attendance and student behavior

 

 How else can I help?

 

  • If you are in the Atlanta Area, Stop by Dance411 Studios (475 Moreland Ave Atlanta, GA 30316) and drop off school supplies

 

  • If you are in the Atlanta Area, Volunteer for Back to School Community Arts Day on August 4, 2012 (http://dance411foundation.org/get-involved)

 

  • Spread the word,  Share this with all your friends!

More About the Dance 411 Foundation

The Dance 411 Foundation provides exposure, services and resources to over 5000 Atlanta children and artists annually. Our programs have been supported by the National Endowment of the Arts, Fulton County Arts Council and Wachovia Bank. Visit www.dance411foundation.org to learn more.

Journey Performing Arts Center, Inc DBA Dance 411 Foundation is a 501c(3) nonprofit. ALL DONATIONS ARE 100% TAX DEDUCTIBLE

story:
Short Summary

Thank you to everyone who helped us to meet and exceed our goal! You can still make donations through this page--and every cent will be greatly appreciated. We are excited to say that every dollar that we will raise through this campaign will be MATCHED by one of our generous funders! What better reason to donate today?

Chess Challenge in DC (CCinDC) uses the game of chess to help at-risk youth develop self-discipline, increase their academic performance, and sense of self-worth.  Incorporating reading and writing literacy and math concepts CCinDC provides after-school activities in DC public schools, charter schools, and other community-based organizations. The program is free to all students. They are provided semi-weekly instruction, source books, take-home chess sets, a T-shirt, and entry into all Chess Challenge in DC tournaments and events.

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to the generosity of an anonymous donor we have the opportunity to give each of our students a Gold Membership in www.ChessKid.com at a very discounted rate. A gold membership usually costs $49.99 per child, per year and it provides options like: endless puzzles, online lessons, and instructional videos. We are going to be able to enroll 200 students for only $800! That is a huge savings for a great program that lets kids have “smart fun” online. 

Simply put, we need $800 that isn't in our budget to take advantage of a unique opportunity to enrich the lives of the students in our program.

For every $4 we raise, we will enroll a student in www.ChessKid.com. 

If for some reason we don't reach our goal we will still enroll as many students as possible based on length in program.

When you donate, you can sign up to receive our newsletter--come out to one of our tournaments and see your donation in action!

The Impact

Chess Challenge in DC has served over 1600 students in over 50 elementary and middle public and public charter schools, and community-based organizations, in Wards 1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 across DC.  Over 55% of our programs are in Wards 7 and 8.

For reading at the middle school level 67% of participants who had an A or B in the 1st quarter maintained that level of performance for the 4th quarter.  Seventy-two percent of those students whose 1st quarter grade was less than a B showed improvement in their 4th quarter grade. 

For math at the middle school level 63% of participants who had an A or B in the first quarter maintained that level of performance for their fourth quarter grade.  Of those students who had less than a B in the 1st quarter 70% showed improvement by the fourth quarter.

Providing students with a ChessKid.com membership will help to  further improve their memorization skills, patience, and sportsmanship. www.ChessKid.com is a 100% safe site that parents and coaches can monitor. We know that providing this membership will enrich the chess experience of CCinDC participants, many of whom are not able to afford the special Gold membership being offered.  

Risks & Challenges

We are not over-reaching in setting our fundraising goal. Any amount raised will enable us to enroll a portion of our students. Of course we know that with your help we can meet or beat our modest goal. If we raise more than our goal (woo! hoo!) we will apply the funds to making our tournaments more fun for our kids (more snacks! more awards!), we can provide coaches with more classroom aides like puzzle books, or we could send some of our top students to out-of-area tournaments. 
We are honored to have been featured as "One of the best small charities in the Greater Washington region" in the 2010-11 and the 2014-15 Catalogue for Philanthropy. 
Other Ways You Can Help
Unable to donate? Please spread the word to friends and family about our campaign!
You can visit our website to learn more about volunteering with CCinDC.
Chess Challenge in DC...Encouraging Success with Each Move

story:
The campaign is over and rewards have been sent out. Go to www.learnyu.com for a demo lesson and write me at judith@learnlangs.com if you still want to purchase any of the perks. Prices may have changed.



    Picture your perfect language tutor: patient, understanding, knowledgeable, perfectly in tune with your needs, and available 24/7.  Now, where would you go to find such a tutor?  How much would you have to pay for a lesson?  Good luck with the unicorn search.  In the meantime, we’ve created LearnYu, an online computer tutor that can be all that and more.

    Inspired by Khan Academy and Duolingo, LearnYu is an intelligent learning system that will automatically optimize your learning program.  As you learn, LearnYu will also learn about you.  It will dynamically generate exercises designed to reinforce your weak points, help you build your vocabulary and improve your conceptual understanding.  With a vast knowledge base and infinite patience and memory, LearnYu is like a superhero language tutor.

    LearnYu's primary focus is spoken Mandarin Chinese. We are now crowdfunding the first level, where you will learn to understand and produce practical phrases -- introducing yourself, talking about your family, your likes and dislikes, the weather and all the juicy small talk. This level will prepare you to take the HSK 1 standardized test to prove your knowledge of Chinese.  We are also already planning the lessons for HSK 2. Besides the bragging right, an HSK certificate can also help you fulfill university requirements and land a better job.


     



    LearnYu is already live and usable, but with limited content. You can already study lessons and review them by reading short passages in Chinese and having conversations with the computer.  Try it for yourself! (Lesson 1 is publicly available, further lessons are only for people supporting this campaign at this point.)

    (see the Gallery for more pictures)

    Development of Level 1 is 50% complete and includes more than 1000 audio recordings (real voices, no machines!). We’ve already recruited more than 100 beta testers, who keep giving us valuable feedback. 

    Your contribution will allow us to complete the work so that we can open the site to the general public. Here are some of the things we will use the money for:

    • Finish writing the remaining lessons of the first level
    • Record audio for new vocabulary and sentences, and edit them for lessons
    • Hire a web designer to ensure LearnYu looks good across different platforms
    • Design more user & AI conversations
    • Add dictionary look-up
    • Support optional lessons based on user interests
    • Improve matching algorithm
    • Allow fuzzy word recognition for simple typos
    • Rework parts of the design
    • Fix various bugs as they get reported

    Over the past year, I have devoted a lot of my personal funds and thousands of hours of sweat and toil to get the system to where it is now.  I’ve managed to build it up to the point where I can show people how this approach can work.  But we still have a way to go to build the learning platform that we envision.  I want to continue to push LearnYu ahead, but I cannot do this without your support.

    But with your support, I’m confident that I will be able to focus all of my attention on LearnYu and recruit the outside help I need to really achieve the level of polish I want. We will be able to complete all of the above tasks and go public before April 2015. We will also start work on level 2, which corresponds to HSK 2.

    Do I need to have Facebook in order to use LearnYu?

    No. Facebook login is convenient because it's a single click, but we can give you a traditional password-based login as well. 

    Will you teach traditional characters as well?

    Yes, by October we will support traditional characters. We already support simplified characters.

    When will you have more levels?

    If this campaign succeeds and we can forge ahead at full speed, we should be able to release a new level every 1-2 months. 

    What if this campaign doesn't reach its funding goal?

    We will still be able to provide all the perks and we will still develop lessons for HSK 2 and beyond. Progress will just be slower than if we could hire Chinese teachers full-time.

    Will you support more languages?

    Creating this kind of site for Chinese or Japanese has vastly different requirements from creating this kind of site for languages written in the Latin alphabet. That's why LearnYu will only do Chinese for the foreseeable future, though we have an agreement with the Esperanto Association of Britain to allow them to use our code to create a site teaching Esperanto. If we did do another language, it would be Japanese. But I'm a firm believer in doing one thing really well rather than trying to do everything in a mediocre way.

    Can my students use LearnYu?

    Yes, contact us for class or school licenses. We will soon also have features for teachers to track their students' progress through the lessons and see the mistakes they make most often.


    LearnYu is a very intuitive course that takes you through one word at a time and with plenty of ways to get the pronunciation repeated, you also learn the tones quite effectively. What I found best with the way the course is built up is that you feel like you are playing a game where you are levelling up, little bars tell you how far you’ve come in the lesson and the greener they are the better you know each individual word.
    I wasn’t really expecting to actually learn a lot, because my mind is full of BA projects, Esperanto and Russian at the moment. But the highly intuitive process of slowly adding words, rather than bombarding you with 20 or more words in one go, really makes you feel like you are just learning Mandarin one step at a time. I even met a Chinese guy in the bar and he was able to understand my basic: “I am Danish”  that’s a huge win.
    -- Chris Broholm, actualfluency.com
    I really recommend you invest in LearnYu if you're a beginner in Chinese. Already, the tool is great to prepare you for HSK 1.  With plans to add more levels and new features, it'll be unstoppable.
    -- Olly Guest, chinesemusings.com


     


    I’m Judith Meyer, the initiator of this project.  I love languages.  Like, seriously.  I’ve learned to speak 12 languages and I’m still learning more!  But of all the languages, I’ve had a special love for Chinese, which has been my particular focus for the past 10 years.  But more than just learning languages on my own, I’m passionate about understanding the language acquisition process and empowering others to learn.  In my blog LearnLangs.com, I’ve shared tips and resources for language learning for years.  I’ve also made a career out of bringing language-learning to new media, having developed web-based language courses for Myngle.com, Innovative Language Learning LLC (GermanPod101, DutchPod101, GreekPod101), and Internet-Live-Seminare, as well as various books I’ve written on the subject.  I hold a degree in Computational Linguistics, the branch of computer science dedicated to developing language-related software.  This gives me a solid technical grounding for the development of this project, which I am leading myself using modern technologies such as Ruby on Rails and jQuery. More about me.

    Marina González is our amazing graphic artist. She graduated with an MA in Fine Arts from the Polytechnic University of Valencia and then moved to Berlin. Marina has been creating the wonderful visuals you can see in the video and on the website. See her full portfolio at marina-mandarina.com.

    Jesse Alter is LearnYu's sysadmin. Based in New Jersey, he ensures that LearnYu.com keeps running.

    Sophia You is a very experienced Chinese teacher. She and her team of native Mandarin speakers in Qingdao, China, have been creating our Chinese lessons and audio recordings.

    Together we are creating the Chinese course of your dreams. Contribute now and share this with your friends!
story_txt:
The campaign is over and rewards have been sent out. Go to www.learnyu.com for a demo lesson and write me at judith@learnlangs.com if you still want to purchase any of the perks. Prices may have changed.




Picture your perfect language tutor: patient, understanding, knowledgeable, perfectly in tune with your needs, and available 24/7.  Now, where would you go to find such a tutor?  How much would you have to pay for a lesson?  Good luck with the unicorn search.  In the meantime, we’ve created LearnYu, an online computer tutor that can be all that and more.
Inspired by Khan Academy and Duolingo, LearnYu is an intelligent learning system that will automatically optimize your learning program.  As you learn, LearnYu will also learn about you.  It will dynamically generate exercises designed to reinforce your weak points, help you build your vocabulary and improve your conceptual understanding.  With a vast knowledge base and infinite patience and memory, LearnYu is like a superhero language tutor.
LearnYu's primary focus is spoken Mandarin Chinese. We are now crowdfunding the first level, where you will learn to understand and produce practical phrases -- introducing yourself, talking about your family, your likes and dislikes, the weather and all the juicy small talk. This level will prepare you to take the HSK 1 standardized test to prove your knowledge of Chinese.  We are also already planning the lessons for HSK 2. Besides the bragging right, an HSK certificate can also help you fulfill university requirements and land a better job.




 






LearnYu is already live and usable, but with limited content. You can already study lessons and review them by reading short passages in Chinese and having conversations with the computer.  Try it for yourself! (Lesson 1 is publicly available, further lessons are only for people supporting this campaign at this point.)

(see the Gallery for more pictures)
Development of Level 1 is 50% complete and includes more than 1000 audio recordings (real voices, no machines!). We’ve already recruited more than 100 beta testers, who keep giving us valuable feedback. 
Your contribution will allow us to complete the work so that we can open the site to the general public. Here are some of the things we will use the money for:


Finish writing the remaining lessons of the first level


Record audio for new vocabulary and sentences, and edit them for lessons


Hire a web designer to ensure LearnYu looks good across different platforms	


Design more user & AI conversations


Add dictionary look-up

Support optional lessons based on user interests


Improve matching algorithm


Allow fuzzy word recognition for simple typos


Rework parts of the design


Fix various bugs as they get reported



Over the past year, I have devoted a lot of my personal funds and thousands of hours of sweat and toil to get the system to where it is now.  I’ve managed to build it up to the point where I can show people how this approach can work.  But we still have a way to go to build the learning platform that we envision.  I want to continue to push LearnYu ahead, but I cannot do this without your support.
But with your support, I’m confident that I will be able to focus all of my attention on LearnYu and recruit the outside help I need to really achieve the level of polish I want. When will you have more levels?

That's why LearnYu will only do Chinese for the foreseeable future, though we have an agreement with the Esperanto Association of Britain to allow them to use our code to create a site teaching Esperanto. If we did do another language, it would be Japanese. But I'm a firm believer in doing one thing really well rather than trying to do everything in a mediocre way.
Can my students use LearnYu?
Yes, contact us for class or school licenses. We will soon also have features for teachers to track their students' progress through the lessons and see the mistakes they make most often.

story:
The University of Warwick Mixed Netball team are going to take part in the suffering run on the 8th of November all in aid for Giving What We Can. Members have chosen to do either a 5k or a 10k run which involves difficult obstacles, short swims and of course the challenge of the distance of the run itself!

Our aim is to raise as much money as we can for a really good cause - Giving What We Can. The money we raise will go far in actually making a difference as Giving What We Can picks charities that do the most with your donations. Our members want to make a difference but they need YOUR help!

Every little helps so any donation is greatly appreciated and will help us reach our target goal of £1000. This money can help a lot of people so THANK YOU in advance from everyone in the club!

If you would like to know more about what members are getting themselves into follow the link below to the suffering page:

http://www.thesufferingrace.co.uk/
